Embryonic stem cells (ESC) have been recently shown to offer a possible solution for low risk induction of hematopoietic multilineage chimerism. This may ultimately lead to tolerance induction after transplantation without or with minimal host preconditioning. Here, we examined whether the constitutively expressed FasL (CD95L) in ESC is a requirement for the induction of stable ESC engraftment using the Fasmutant MRL lpr/lpr mouse, which does not express functional Fas (CD95). Three mouse derived ESC lines, C57BL/6, 129SvJ R1 and the 129SvJ RW-4, were characterized and used for these studies. Characteristically, all cell lines expressed very low levels of MHC class I antigens, no class II antigens, high levels of stage-specific embryonic antigen-1 (SSEA-1) and FasL. One of the 3 cell lines, 129SvJ RW4 ESC (H-2K b ) showed high proliferation and virtually no class I expression. This cell line was further used for the induction of mixed chimerism. ESC were infused into the supra-orbital vein of allogeneic MRL (H-2K k ) lpr/lpr mice (n=7). The MRL wild type mice were used as controls (n=7). Chimerism was studied by flow cytometry of whole blood leukocytes on days 7, 14 and 28 post ESC infusion and defined as co-expression of H-2 b and any of the CD markers CD3, CD19, CD14, CD16&32 or NK1.1. At day 14, over 85 % of wild type mice showed mixed chimerism compared to less than 30 % in lpr/lpr mice. By day 28, still more than 70 % of wild type mice maintained chimerism, versus none in lpr/lpr mice. Mixed chimerism was generally between 5-10 % in peripheral blood. These results suggest that Fas-FasL interaction is a requirement for the induction of stable mixed chimerism in mice, presumably due to the induction of apoptosis to alloreactive T cells by ESC. Indeed, immunohistochemical staining of chimeric wild type mice showed massive induction of apoptosis in the thymus, spleen and liver, indicating the role of apoptosis in ESC engraftment. Thus, our studies provide a rationale for studying ESC as an alternative to bone marrow cells for the induction of mixed chimerism with minimal host pre-conditioning and underscore the role of Fas/FasL engagement in ESC engraftment. Background: Recently, pigs that lack the gene for α-1,3galactosyltransferase (GalT-KO pigs) have been bred using nuclear transfer technology on a MGH miniature swine background (SLA dd ). We studied whether GalT-KO pigs develop anti-Gal antibodies (Abs) (as do GalT-KO mice) and also their cellular response to wild-type (Gal +/+ ) MHCmatched (SLA dd ) pig cells. Methods: Tissues from GalT-KO pigs (n=5) were examined for their expression of Gal by the immunoperoxidase technique using the biotinylated lectin, Griffonia simplicifolia (IB4). The presence of anti-Gal Abs in the sera was determined by ELISA. Abs to MHC-matched (SLA dd ) Gal +/+ miniature swine cells were determined by flow cytometry (FACS). Cytotoxicity assays were performed to assess whether the Abs, if present, were cytotoxic to Gal +/+ SLA dd peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC). Cellular responses of GalT-KO miniature swine to Gal +/+ SLA dd miniature swine were examined by mixed lymphocyte reactivity (MLR) and cell-mediated lympholysis (CML) assays. Results: None of the GalT-KO pigs showed any Gal expression on histological staining of all major tissues. Their sera contained anti-Gal IgM Abs by ELISA. FACS demonstrated binding of GalT-KO sera to Gal +/+ SLA dd PBMC. IgM Abs were present in the sera of 2 pigs and both IgM and IgG Abs in 3 pigs. Sera with IgM Abs alone were weakly cytotoxic, while those with IgM+IgG were strongly cytotoxic to Gal +/+ PBMC, but treatment with dithiothreitol (DTT) rendered the sera non-cytotoxic, revealing that most of the cytotoxicity was due to IgM Abs. MLR and CML assays revealed no T cell response by GalT-KO pigs to their Gal +/+ MHC-matched counterparts. There was no correlation between the age of the pig and the Ab status. Conclusions: GalT-KO pigs develop cytotoxic anti-Gal Abs, primarily IgM, but have no increased T cell reactivity to MHC-matched Gal +/+ pigs. These data suggest that the transplantation of organs from Gal +/+ pigs into MHC-matched GalT-KO pigs may be a clinically-relevant large animal model in which to study mechanisms of accommodation or B cell tolerance. BK virus (BKV) is a significant factor in the failure of renal transplants. Polyomavirus establishes a persistent silent infection in most immunocompetent individuals. However, in the setting of immunosuppression, viral replication and pathology may ensue. To date no animal model has been described to investigate the pathogenesis of BKV associated nephropathy. Methods: Transplantation of either B6 or C3H kidneys into B6 recipients with or without native nephrectomy was performed with or without polyoma infection. Viral titers and virulence were measured by real time PCR and plaque assay. Renal allograft was assessed histologically and functionally (serum creatinine). Cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) assay and flow cytometry was used to quantitate antiviral and antidonor responses. Results: Mice with renal allografts develop chronic rejection but survive >60 days without immunosuppression. Polyoma virus precipitates accelerated destruction of allografts (MST 11±2) but not isografts (MST>60). Furthermore, we found >1000-fold higher levels of virus in allogeneic as compared to syngeneic kidney transplants. Tissue damage was markedly greater and creatinine significantly higher in polyoma infected renal allografts compared to uninfected allografts or infected isografts (n=5, 1.7 vs. 0.3, 0.5 mg/dL, P<0.0007, 0.0019). To show recipient restricted viral clearance, mice were acutely infected after orthotopic allogeneic kindey trasplantation. Allograft kidneys had markedly elevated levels of virus compared to the native kidney (1x10 8 vs. 1x10 4 copies/mg, P<0.02). Lastly, we observed that the anti-donor CD8+T cell response was greater in renal allograft recipients with infection compared to uninfected recipients. However, ICCS and CTL assay with donor specific stimulation showed that infection alone does not induce cross-reactivity. Conclusion: These data indicate that polyoma virus promotes rapid destruction of renal allografts. Nephropathy is associated with an inability to clear virus from an MHC disparate organ, but not a syngeneic transplant or native kidney. Polyoma infection significantly augments the anti-donor T cell responsive to a kidney allograft. However, infection without an allogeneic kidney transplant fails to induce virusspecific T cells that are cross-reactive against the donor. Using this novel model of polyoma associated nephropathy, we hope to discover insights into the pathogenesis and develop new therapies for this major clinical problem. We have developed a novel strategy to inhibit expression of B7 molecules (CD80/86) by transfecting with a gene construct encoding a modified CTLA4 molecule (CTLA4-KDEL). The KDEL sequence serves to retain this molecule in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), where it binds to CD80/86 molecules, preventing them from moving out of the ER, through the Golgi and onto the cell surface. Human APCs, including B cells and dendritic cells, expressing this construct did not express CD80/86 on their surface. They showed normal expression of other cell surface molecules. They were unable to stimulate allogeneic and peptide-specific T cell responses and induced antigen specific anergy of the responding T cells. Cells expressing CTLA4-KDEL did not upregulate the indoleamine 2, 3-dioxygenase (IDO) enzyme, unlike the cells treated with soluble CTLA4-Ig. This gene-based strategy to inhibit expression of key surface receptors is an attractive alternative to the use of immature DCs (iDCs) for prevention of transplant rejection.

Background: Various equations have been utilized to estimate renal function (fcn) among renal allograft recipients. Implications of equation choice to clinical studies are unknown. Three equations (MDRD(4-variable), Cockgroft-Gault (CG) and the Nankivell A (NankA) formulae are frequently used, and were compared in this study. Methods: From 1990-2000, there were 387 renal allograft recipients from a living donor transplanted at UPMC. Among these persons, 287 had data that allowed for the calculation of the 3 formulae understudy. Cross-sectional comparisons were made at 3 months and longitudinal changes were made over the first year. Potential relevance of the variances between equations was explored by using: 1) threshold of 70 ml/min for study entry; 2) proportion of subjects in strata (>90, <=90& >70, <=70 & >50, <=50 & >=30, <30 ml/min) that allow for stratified randomization, or for sampling strategies; 3) change of renal function as an outcome. Results: See Table. Means of the renal fcn at 3 months are different (P<0.0001, F test) with higher estimates by MDRD and CG compared to Nankivell (P<0.001, P<0.001), and by MDRD compared to CG (P<0.0001); proportions of subjects having >=70ml/ min are different (P<0.001, chi square); proportions of subjects within strata are different with Kappa statistics indicating only fair agreement across formulae considering chance; and change of renal fcn over one year is significantly different (P=0.04, F test). Conclusions: The choice of equation and the clinically relevant differences between them can have a significant impact in clinical trials or observational studies on: 1) eligibility rates; 2) efficiency of sampling or randomization strategies; 3) power; and 4) comparability of results between studies. 5) A measure(s) of cross-sectional and longitudinal renal fcn, across the distribution of GFR, which is confirmed to be a valid and reliable standard among recipients of renal allografts should be developed.

Myocardial infarction is a frequent complication after renal transplantation. Pre-transplant screening for coronary artery disease in patients undergoing renal transplantation may improve outcome in post transplant period. The aim of the study was to determine if dobutamine stress echocardiography (DSE) is a good predictor of myocardial infarction in first year after transplantation. Methods. We did a chart review of 800 patients that had undergone renal transplantation at Henry Ford Hospital between 1990-2001. Of the 800, only 179 had stress testing at our institution or were followed at our institution after their transplantation. We divided the patients into those who underwent dobutamine stress echo, nuclear stress test or other cardiac testing. The groups were then followed for one year. Any patient who had a troponin >3 ng/ml were considered to have had a myocardial infarction. Results. 179 patients underwent stress testing and were followed at our institution. Of these, 67 had DSE, 55 had nuclear stress testing, 41 had other testing done. From the DSE group, 11 were lost to follow up, 4 had a positive stress test, and 52 had a negative stress test. Among the nuclear stress test group, 10 were lost to follow up, 13 had a positive stress test and 32 had a negative test. A total of 8 patients had a myocardial infarction, 5 were from the group who had a negative DSE and 1 was from the group of 4 patients with positive DSE. 1 patient had myocardial infarction from the group who had a negative nuclear stress test and 1 out of 32 patients who tested negative with nuclear stress test had an ischemic cardiac event. The positive predictive value for DSE was 25% and for nuclear stress test was 7.8%. The negative predictive values were 90.1% and 96.9%, respectfully. Conclusion. The association of ACE gene polymorphism with post renal transplant hypertension is far from clear. We studied the ACE gene polymorphisms in 42 patients with post transplant hypertension on maintenance doses of immunosuppression, normal allograft functions with no proteinuria and no evidence of renal artery stenosis. The DD genotype was seen in 93%, ID genotype in 5% and II genotype in 2% as compared to 40%, 52% and 8% respectively in patients with essential hypertension and 31%, 47% and 22% respectively in normotensive control Indian population (p<0.05). TABREF26.text: Purpose: Hyperlipidemia is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in renal transplant recipients. A retrospective review was conducted to determine the safety and efficacy of a new cholesterol agent, ezetimibe (Zetia®), as an alternative treatment option for this patient population. Statin therapy was first line therapy for hyperlipidemia in all patients. Criteria for ezetimibe combination therapy was if the fasting lipid profile did not meet the NCEP III guideline goals for high risk patients after 6 weeks on another agent or reaching the maximum dose of that agent before acheiving goal. Monotherapy was initiated with ezetimibe if the patient did not tolerate the first line agent (s). Monotherapy was started in 3 patients, who had all previously failed statins, and combination therapy was utilized in 17 patients. Prior to ezetimibe therapy 5 patients had a TC <200mg/dl, 7 patients had a TG<150mg/dl, 10 patients had an HDL >60mg/dl and 4 patients had an LDL<100mg/dl. However, none of the patients had reached their lipid goal with the first-line agents. After therapy, 11 patients had a TC<200mg/dl, 12 patients had a TG<150mg/dl, 10 patients had an HDL >60mg/dl and 12 patients had an LDL <100mg/ dl. The average reduction in TC and LDL was 20.9% and 24.5%, respectively, after 4.5 months of therapy. Two patients were switched from cyclosporine to tac after ezetimibe was initiated due to toxicity. The cya dose was decreased in 1 patient when diltiazem was initiated. There were no other alterations in cya or tacrolimus levels and no adverse events were attributable to ezetimibe treatment. Conclusions: Ezetimibe as combination or monotherapy is a safe and effective treatment option for hyperlipidemia in renal transplant recipients without changes in CI levels.Hyperlipidemia and hypertryglyceridemia are known side effects of sirolimus immunosuppression therapy. Markedly elevated total and LDL cholesterol levels have often been cited as a reason for discontinuing sirolimus in renal transplant recipients. While most cases of sirolimus induced hyperlipidemia can be treated with single agent statin therapy, some patients require additional measures. We report successful reductions in total and LDL cholesterol in sirolimus treated renal transplant recipients using combination therapy with atorvastatin and slow release niacin. although no patient had to be discontinued from the niacin. The mean dose at 6 months was 1000 mg per day. One patient had to be briefly withdrawn for acute gouty arthritis. No elevation in creatinine kinase levels was observed. Two patients had transaminase elevations, which improved when the dose of niacin was reduced. Despite improvements, no patient achieved NCEP recommended guidelines.Conclusions: The regimen of atorvastatin with slow release niacin can lower total and LDL cholesterol in patients with post-transplant hyperlipidemia on sirolimus based immunosuppression therapy. TABREF86.text: Short-term combination therapy with immunosuppressive drugs and costimulation blockade has demonstrated considerable success in preventing graft rejection in a variety of transplant models. However, the rate of successful graft acceptance varies considerably depending on the type of tissue transplanted. In a fully MHC-mismatched mouse model, we have previously shown that costimulation blockade of the inducible costimulator molecule (ICOS) in combination with cyclosporine induces permanent abdominal cardiac allograft survival, but does not facilitate renal subcapsular islet allograft survival. We herein explored the possible factors responsible for the divergent findings in cardiac and islet allograft survival in this model. Methods. BALB/c mice were used as donors for islet and cardiac tissue, while intact or splenectomized and renal lymph node resected B6 mice were used as recipients. Islet transplantation was performed under the renal capsule of streptozotocin-treated diabetic recipients, while heterotopic abdominal or renal subcapsular cardiac transplantation was completed in normal recipients. Transplanted mice were treated with anti-ICOS mAb (12A8, 0.1 mg/d) and cyclosporine (10 mg/kg/d). Reagents were administered i.p. for 14 days. Results. The divergent findings between cardiac and islet allograft survival may be related to the site of transplantation and the presence of intact lymphatic drainage in recipient kidneys. This is based on the findings that a) unlike abdominal cardiac transplants, cardiac tissue transplanted under the renal capsule of mice receiving 12A8 + cyclosporine was rejected, and b) recipient mice undergoing splenectomy and renal lymph node resection at the time of islet transplantation and combination treatment demonstrated significantly prolonged graft survival compared to recipient mice maintaining normal lymphatic drainage (MST=33 vs 17 days respectively, p<0.01). Conclusions. The highest Foxp3 expression levels were found during acute rejection (p=0.01) and correlated with IL-2 and TCR mRNA expression levels (p=0.01 and p<0.0001, respectively). Our results demonstrate that immune regulatory mechanisms are induced within the transplanted heart during acute rejection. Both Foxp3+ T-cells and FLIP controlled AICD are involved in this process. Edwards, 2 Ann Harper.2 1 Division  of Transplant Surgery, Department of Surgery, Boston, MA; 2 Research Division, United Network for  Organ Sharing, Richmond, VA.    original MELD/PELD liver allocation plan allowed candidates with Stage I and Stage II HCC to receive 24 and 29 MELD points respectively to approximate a 15% and 30% risk of progression beyond Stage II. Early results indicated that, at this level of priority, these candidates had an extremely high 90-day transplant rate and essentially no drop out rate. In deference to standard MELD score candidates who experienced much lower transplant rates and higher death rates compared with HCC candidates under the original policy, HCC priority was reduced to 20 and 24 points for Stage I and Stage II candidates on 2/27/03. To determine the effect of this change we used a competing risk approach to compare the cumulative probability of still waiting, and removal for transplant, death/too sick, or other reason at 30, 45 60 and 90 days after listing for candidates granted increased priority due to their HCC diagnosis before (N= 834) and after (N=390) 2/27/03. After the policy change, HCC candidates experienced a trend toward increased probability of still waiting that did not reach statistical significance at any time point. We found a significant reduction in cumulative probability of transplant at 45(42.1% vs. 31.0%), 60 (50.4% vs. 35.9%) and 90 (58.2% vs. 44.9%) days after listing. The cumulative probability for removal for death/too sick did not change with the change in HCC policy for 30 (1.20% vs. 0.26%), 45 (1.68% vs. 0.26%), 60 (2.52% vs. 0.51%), and 90 (3.36% vs. 3.59%) day endpoints. The cumulative probability for removal due to other reasons was also unchanged with the new lower HCC priority (0.48% vs. 0.26% at 30, 0.60% vs. 0.51% at 45, 0.84% vs. 0.77% at 60 and 1.32% vs. 1.79% at 90 days). Our results support recent single center reports of very low drop out rates for early stage HCC at 90 days. The reduction in HCC priority resulted in lower probability of transplant for HCC candidates but did not increase their drop out rate as measured by probability of removal for death/too sick or other reason. HCC candidates still have a high probability of transplant within 90 days even after the reduction in HCC priority. DECEASED DONOR LIVER TRANSPLANT SURVIVAL RATES UNDER THE MELD/PELD SYSTEM. Methods: A standardized staffing survey tool was developed by the TAC which surveyed the areas of: 1.) work volume indicators (txp, referrals, evaluation, living donor workups, clinic visits and listed patients); 2.) number of dedicated txp staff; 3.) identification of tasks being performed. An email notification in February 2003 was sent to 254 txp centers in the U.S. requesting voluntary participation in this survey. 127 txp centers responded representing 289 txp programs. The analysis focused on Kidney, Liver and Heart txp programs which accounted for 177 of the complete and evaluable surveys. Results: National averge work volume indicators and average staffing complements in full time equivelants (FTEs) were analyzed for Kidney, Liver and Heart txp programs and are shown in the table. Conclusion: This survey provides the first standardized evidenced-based txp staffing patterns in the U.S. There are substantial resources necessary to provide access to transplantation, managing listed patients and post-txp follow-up for life. Due to these increasing patient volume issues, creative staffing resources are being used to streamline and improve clinical and administrative effectiveness. Among them, txp nurse practitioners, physician assistants and txp coordinator assistants. The survey does not take into account txp administration business staff. POST M.E.L.D. ERA. TABREF241.text: LIVER TRANSPLANTATION FOR DRUG INDUCED LIVER INJURY IN THE UNITED STATES.Mark W. Russo, 1 Roshan Shrestha,1 Michael W. Fried, 1 Paul Watkins.1 1 Medicine, University of North  Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC.    drug induced liver injury (DILI) is an important medical problem and studies of acute liver failure and DILI have included cases that are mostly from acetaminophen overdose and have not reported post-transplant outcomes(Ann Intern Med  202;137:947). Aim: To identify the drugs most commonly reported to lead to liver transplantation from DILI and to determine if gender and race are associated with liver transplantation for DILI. Methods: We used the United Network for Organ Sharing liver transplant database to identify recipients who underwent liver transplantation for DILI from 1989-October 31, 2002. Patients were identified if their diagnosis was acute hepatic necrosis from a drug and if they were UNOS status 1 at the time of transplant. Patients were excluded if they had a prior organ transplant, or if they were diagnosed with DILI, but a specific drug was not identified. The text of the database was manually searched to determine if a specific drug was identified as the cause of acute liver failure. Results: 267 recipients who had a liver transplant for acute liver failure from DILI were identified. The characteristics of the study group are in theTable.The most common cause of DILI from other drugs (n=146) were isoniazid (INH) n=24 (16%), propylthiouracil n=13 (8.9%), phenytoin n=10 (6.8%) and valproate n=10(6.8%). Complementary-alternative medicine was reported in 13 (8.9%) of this group, with Amanita mushrooms accounting for 7 cases. Women were more prevalent then men in both the acetaminophen and other drug groups. Among recipients receiving a liver transplant due to INH, African-Americans were more prevalent than Whites 16% and 5.9%, p=0.03. Liver transplantation for INH DILI was more common in African-American women compared to White women, OR=3.9 [95%CI 1.3, 11.9], p=0.02. One-year graft survival in the acetaminophen group and other drugs were 68% and 71%, respectively, p=0.17 and one-year patient survival was 78% and 71%, respectively, p=0.15. Conclusions: Young women are the group most commonly affected by DILI leading to liver transplantation. The drugs most commonly associated with DILI and liver transplantation other than acetaminophen are isoniazid, propylthiouracil, phenytoin and valproate. Liver transplantation for INH DILI is most common in African-American women. STUDY. James V. Guarrera, Maximillian Polyak, Ben O'Mar Arrington, Jean C. Emond, William T. Stubenbord,Milan  Kinkhabwala. Organ Preservation Unit, New York Presbyterian Hospital,  New York, NY; Center for Liver Disease and Transplantation, College of  Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY; Division  of Transplant Surgery, Weill Medical College, Cornell University, New  York, NY.   :  We have reported improved graft function in kidneys preserved with Vasosol® preservation solution. Vasosol® utilizes elements of conventional University of Wisconsin (UW) solution with additional vasodilatory and antioxidant components including PGE1, Nitroglycerine and N-acetylcysteine. We modified Vasosol® for normothermic preservation by altering electrolyte composition and adding bovine hemoglobin and enriched tissue media for as substrate for metabolism. We investigated warm oxygenated preservation with this solution in a porcine liver model of ischemia/ reperfusion (I/R) injury. Methods: 20 miniature swine (16-22kg) underwent standard liver procurement after 120 min of in-situ warm ischemia via pringle clamping and were randomized to 24h UW cold storage (4°C) or 24h normothermic machine perfusion (35-37°C)(NMP) with modified Vasosol®. NMP was performed using a Waters Mox 100 pulsatile perfusion machine modified with a roller pump for portal perfusion and a membrane oxygenator. After the 24h preservation period both groups were reperfused with autologous blood for 8h and compared. Perfusate and bile assays were performed. Transmission electron microscopy was used to evaluate ultrastructural injury. Data are expressed as mean± SD. P values <0.05 were considered significant. Student's T-test and Mann-Whitney U tests were used for statistical analysis. Results: Livers preserved with NMP had superior metabolic, synthetic and hemodynamic function compared to the cold stored livers. Ultrastructural damage was less in the warm perfused group.Conclusions: Normothermic oxygenated preservation with modified Vasosol® significantly decreases I/R injury in a porcine liver model. Clinical studies of this technique are now indicated. Normothermic perfusion may improve early graft function and increase the donor supply by allowing improved results with liver from "marginal" and nonheartbeating donors. AIM: To compare Celsior solution (CS) with gold standard University of Wisconsin (UW) solution in orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT). METHODS: From May 2001 to October 2003, 80 adult liver transplant recipients were randomised prospectively to receive either CS (n=40) or UW(n=40). CS and UW infusion volume was 4 and 3 L through aorta respectively, 2 L through portal vein and 1 L at back table through portal vein. All OLT were done with the piggyback technique. RESULTS: Both groups were comparable with regard to donor characteristics: age, cause of death, ICU stay, hypotension episodes, cardiac arrest, vasoactive drug requirement, steatosis, billirubin, AST/ALT, INR, and sodium. Cold ischemia time was 380± 96 minutes for CS and 432 ± 148 for UW (p=0.3). No cases of primary non-function and graft dysfunction occurred in both groups. Patient actuarial survival at 3 m, 6m, 12 m and 24 m was 93%, 90%, 86% and 86% for the CS group and 93%, 90%, 80%and 80% for the UW group. Graft actuarial survival at 1m, 3 m, 6m, 12 m and 24 m was 94%, 88%, 85%, 78% and 78% for the CS group and 94%, 88%, 85%, 75% and 66% for the UW group. No significant differences were seeing in both groups regarding graft and patient survival. CONCLUSIONS: Celsior solution is as safe as the U. Wisconsin solution in liver graft preservation within the cold ischemic time considered. No primary non-function and graft dysfunction occurred with both solutions. Further studies are needed to confirm the same efficacy with longer cold ischemic times. Long term application of MMF has been proven safe in children and young adults. Discontinuation or dose adjustments of MMF due to tolerability problems constitute a risk factor increasing the incidence of AR. Enteric-coated mycophenolate sodium (EC-MPS, myfortic®) was designed to improve gastrointestinal (GI) tolerability. EC-MPS 720 mg is equimolar to MMF 1000 mg. Materials and Methods: An open, 6-month, multicenter, prospective trial has been conducted to demonstrate the safety and tolerability of the conversion from MMF to EC-MPS among stable renal transplant patients. In the setting of a trial involving several countries, three sites enrolled children. A total of 19 pediatric patients aged 14.2±3.0 years were included, 13 Caucasians, 1 African American, and 5 other, 12 males and 7 females, mean post tx time 3.6±3.1 years. The children were receiving MMF at a dose of 457±147 mg/m 2 b.i.d. (manufacturer suggested dose 600 mg/m 2 b.i.d), and were converted to 432±51 mg/m² b.i.d of EC-MPS, which represents a higher amount of mycophenolic acid per m². Patients were also treated with Neoral ( mean C2levels 764±400 ng/ml), and steroids as per center standard of practice. Results: After the conversion, the incidence of any adverse event (AE) was 63% , 42% gastrointestinal (GI) AEs: 16% upper GI, and 21% diarrhea. The incidence of infections was 52.6%. Neither CMV infection/disease episodes, nor hematological AEs were reported. No patient discontinued the study medication. AEs subsided upon dose reduction. There were no episodes of acute rejection, death or graft loss. Conclusions: The conversion to EC-MPS from MMF was safe in this pediatric population. TABREF251.text: CAMPATH-1H USE IN PEDIATRIC RENAL TRANSPLANTATION.Sharon M. Bartosh,1 Hans W. Sollinger.2 1  Pediatrics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI; 2 Surgery, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI. -1H is a humanized, monoclonal antibody directed against CD52 determinants on the surface of human B-and T-cells and monocytes. Preliminary reports of Campath-1H use as induction in adult renal transplantation have been encouraging with low rejection rates and minimal adverse side effects. We report 3 pediatric kidney transplant patients who received Campath-1H for unique indications with variable results. Patient #1 was a 10 yr old female who had lost 2 prior cadaveric transplants to poorly controlled, progressive acute rejection episodes. She received a third cadaver kidney (zero HLA match), 1 dose of Campath-1H along with prednisone, mycophenolate and tacrolimus. She is now 7 mos post transplant and has experienced no rejection, or PTLD and has a creat of 0.7 mg/dl. She was treated at 6 mos post transplant for herpes zoster. Patient #2 is a 20 month old male with ESRD secondary to Factor H deficiency-associated atypical HUS. He received a cadaveric kidney, 1 dose of campath-1H, prednisone and mycophenolate mofetil. He experienced severe, antibody-mediated rejection on POD# 21. Rejection was controlled with a combination of corticosteroids, plasmapheresis, thymoglobulin, rituximab and immune globulin. Sirolimus was begun after the rejection was reversed. 6 months post transplant, he has stable renal function (creatinine 0.2 mg/ dl) with no infection or PTLD. He has had no hematologic evidence of recurrence of HUS. Patient #3 is a 15 yr old with ESRD secondary to FSGS. She received a cadaveric renal transplant, 1 dose of Campath-1H, prednisone, cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil. She experienced immediate recurrence of her FSGS as well as antibody-mediated rejection POD # 35. She was treated with plasmapheresis, thymoglobulin and higher doses of calcineurin inhibitor.

TABREF252.text: DRUG MONITORING OF MYCOPHENOLIC ACID (MPA) IN THE LONG TERM FOLLOW UP OF PEDIATRIC TRANSPLANT RECIPIENTS: TROUGH LEVELS ARE NO GOOD INDICATOR FOR LONG TERM GRAFT FUNCTION.Lars Pape,1 Jochen H. H. Ehrich, 1 Juergen Strehlau, 1 Gisela Offner.1 1 Department of Pediatric  Nephrology, Medical School of Hannover, Hannover, Germany.    Background: Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) has the potential for decreasing acute rejection episodes early after renal transplantation and pharmocokinetic monitoring of MPA trough levels is done by many centers. Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) has also been shown to improve long term graft function in patients with chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN), however, no data for long term monitoring of MPA have been published in children. Methods: MMF therapy with a dose of 600 mg/m²/d was initiated in 42 children (median age 9.4 years, range 1.4-15.1) after a median period of 3.8 years (range 1.0-10.6) post transplantation according to significant increases in serum-creatinine. CAN was diagnosed by renal biopsy and the amount of fibrosis was quantified by PicroSirius Red staining. MMF-therapy was combined with Cyclosporin A and Prednisolone. MPA-C0-levels, measured by HPLC, were taken every 3 months and in 12 children a full MPA -area under the curve concentration (AUC) was measured. The GFR was calculated at the start of MMF therapy and 2 years later. Results: After initiation of MMF the calculated GFR did not decrease further in 22 children and mean GFR remained stable for 2 years in the whole study group. There was a significant correlation between MPA levels 75 minutes after administration and the full AUC (r=0.94, p<0.001) but no correlation between trough levels and AUC (r=-0.07, p>0.05). The mean MPA trough level was 2.8±1.3 ng/ml. The intra-individual coefficient of variation was 2.6±1.4. There was no correlation between mean MPA trough levels and GFR development after two years (r=0.03, p>0.05) or between MMF-dose and MPA trough level (r=-0.1, p>0.05). In children with an MPA-level below 1.2 mg/ l (n=5), the mean GFR was not different from those with a higher level (p>0.05). Conclusions: MMF Therapy had a positive effect on CAN, however, drug monitoring of MPA-trough levels had no impact on long term graft function in kidney recipients. MPA levels taken 75 minutes after administration showed a high correlation with MPA-AUC whereas C0-levels did not correlate. The value of C75 drug measurements for monitoring renal allograft survival will have to be determined in future studies.

Tan, 1 Akhtar Khan, 1 Edward A. Gray, 1 Parmjeet S.Randhawa,1 Noriko Murase,1 Adriana Zeevi, 1 Anthony J. Demetris, 1 Jennifer Woodward, 1 Velma P. Scantlebury, 1 Mark L. Starzl Transplantation Institute,  University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA.    have suggested that the heavy conventional immunosuppression used for organ transplantation subverts the seminal tolerogenic mechanism of clonal exhaustiondeletion and thereby contributes to long-term drug-dependence. This self-defeating effect was avoided in 175 adult kidney recipients (mean 49.9 ± 14.3 years) treated between July 2001 and September 2003; 43 (24.6%) had adjunct donor bone marrow cell infusion. Two therapeutic principles were applied: (1) recipient pretreatment (with 5mg/kg Thymoglobulin) (2) minimal post-transplant immunosuppression (with tacrolimus monotherapy, initial target trough 10ng/ml). 25 (14.2%) patients were undergoing retransplantation, and 34 (19.4 %) had a PRA >20%. Mean HLA mismatches were 3.1 ± 1.7. 100 kidneys (57 %) were cadaveric (mean cold ischemia 25.6 ± .7 hours) and 95 (43 %) were from living donors. Mean donor age was 39.9 ± 6.3 years (range 1 -66). Post-transplant doses of tacrolimus were spaced to every other day or longer at various times after 4 months. With a mean follow up of 16.9 ± 7.1 months, the actuarial one and 2-year patient survival is 97% and 95%, with graft survival of 91% and 84%. Mean current serum creatinine is 1.95 ± 1.14 mg/dl. The incidence of preweaning acute clinical rejection was 34.9% (6.3% steroid resistant). Weaning was attempted in 149 cases (85.1%) and interrupted by rejection in 45 (30.2%). Currently, 111 (63.4 %) patients are at various stages of weaning: 25 (14.2%) every other day, 44 (25.1%) 3 x/ week, 28 (16%) 2 x/week, and 14 (8%) once/week. 10% of patients had asymptomatic CMV infection and there was one BK infection, and one case of transient post-transplant diabetes, but the incidence of CMV disease and PTLD was 0%. With significant numbers of highly weaned patients beyond the two-year mark, we continue to apply this strategy of immunosuppression, which is neither drug nor organ specific.CYCLOSPORINE WITHDRAWAL FROM A MYCOPHENOLATE MOFETIL-CONTAINING IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE REGIMEN: RESULTS OF A FIVE-YEAR, PROSPECTIVE, RANDOMIZED STUDY.Daniel Abramowicz, 1 Nesrin Gafner, 2 Peter Wijngaard.2 1 Hopital  Erasme, Bruxelles, Belgium; Basel, Switzerland.    BACKGROUND: Long-term maintenance immunosuppression with cyclosporine (CsA) is associated with nephrotoxicity, hyperlipidaemia, and hypertension. In 1999, a 12-month, randomized, multicentre study involving 187 patients, indicated that CsA withdrawal from a mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)-based regimen resulted in improved graft function at the cost of a slight increase in the incidence of rejection episodes. This 4-year, follow-up (FU) study investigates the long-term efficacy and safety of the CsAfree regimen. METHODS: 151 stable renal transplant recipients entered follow-up. 77 patients were maintained on CsA (mean dose 217 mg/day), MMF (mean dose 1.9 g/day), and steroids (mean dose 6.5 mg/day) [CsA-MMF GROUP], whilst the remaining 74 were administered with a CsA-free regimen of MMF (mean dose 2.0 g/day) and steroids (mean dose 9.5 mg/day) [MMF GROUP]. Baseline characteristics were similar for both groups.

Outcome following renal transplantation is influenced by several interdependent factors. This study was designed to test the hypothesis that graft outcome can be enhanced by close follow-up thus increased compliance of patients. Aim: To assess graft survival of patients enrolled in post-transplant studies (high compliance group) versus control group not enrolled in any post-transplant studies (low compliance group). Patients enrolled in studies had more aggressive follow-up then non-study patients. Patients and Methods: From Jan 1996 to Dec. 2002, we performed 1718 renal transplants. Patients were enrolled in 20+ post-transplant Phase II and III clinical trial studies (high-compliance group) at 23% (n = 389) of our transplanted population and were compared to control group of 77% (n=1328) patients not enrolled in any post-transplant studies. Anova, T-Test and Kaplan Meier were used for analyses.

back_matter.text: Aim: Several enzyme preparations are available for islet isolation. One of them is a highly purified product with separate components which allow adaptation of neutral protease concentration. Study aim was to evaluate the role of neutral protease for islet isolation. Methods: Seven groups of SD rats (18 rats/group) were designed for standardized islet isolation. We used in group I, collagenase type XI at 2mg/ml (Sigma Chemical), in group II Liberase at 0.6mg/ml (Roche) and in group III to VII collagenase NB1 0.6mg/ ml (Serva Electrophoresis). In group III, pure collagenase NB1 was used. In group IV, V, VI and VII concentration of 7.5, 15, 22 and 30 mg/ml neutral protease (NP) were added, respectively. Results were analyzed in term of islet equivalent (IE) yields, apoptosis, Cytokine (IL-1b, IL-6, TNFa, IFNg) secretions, insulin secretion (static incubation) and islet morphology. Results: Endotoxin contents of enzyme solution were for group I and II of 170 and 120 EU/ml. Among group III to VII it gradually increased, according to the NP concentration, from 0.4 to 58 EU/ml (p<0.05). IE yields per rat were of 1367 ±522 and 1755 ±110 for group I and II, respectively. Among group III to VII, IE yields per rat followed a Gaussian distribution according to NP concentration with higher yield for group V, 1712 ±245, and lower for group III (597 ±277) and VII (905 ±297) (p<0.05). Among group III to VII, islet morphology was influenced by the NP concentration with decreasing number of trapped islet and increasing number of fragmented islet as the NP content increased. Increase in NP concentration was associated with progressive damage to the islet, which was similar in group VII to the damage observed in group I and II. Cytokines release were lower in group III to VII in comparison to group I and II, but were not influenced by NP concentration. Islet cell apoptosis was statistically significantly lower in group III to VII in comparison to group I and II, but was not influenced by NP concentration. Mean insulin secretion stimulation indexes were of 2.96 for group I, 5.17 for group II and between 5.25 and 5.43 for group III to VII.Introduction: According to UNOS/IPTR data, since 1999 proportionally more transplants (txs) have been done in solitary pancreas (pa) tx categories (pa after kidney [kd] tx [PAK], pa tx alone [PTA]) than in the simult. pa and kd tx (SPK) category. For SPK, both multi-and single center studies have shown increased patient (pt) survival rates as compared with deceased kd txs alone (KTA) in diabetic pts. For PAK and PTA, we determined impact of solitary pa tx on pt survival rates by comparing tx mortality vs. waiting list mortality. Methods: Between Jan 1, 1995 and May 20, 2003, 3094 diabetic patients were listed for PAK and 1149 for PTA. For data analysis, several criteria were used: (1) pts listed for or who previously underwent non-renal tx were excluded; (2) pts with multiple listings at different centers were counted only once (with waiting times added from date of first listing); (3) pts whose recipient category was changed were censored. We identified all pts who died on, or who were removed from, the waiting list. The Social Security Death Master File (SSDMF) supplemented follow-up in the UNOS/IPTR data base. Uni-and multivariate analyses for mortality assessment on the waiting list versus after tx were performed. For univariate analysis, unadjusted survival rates were calculated using Kaplan Meier. Mortality on the waiting list was calculated from time of listing; after pa tx, from time of tx, disregarding waiting time. Time-dependent causes of death were categorized as tx-, diabetes-, or non-tx/non-diabetes-related. For multivariate analysis, only risk factors for both wait-listed and transplanted pts were included (pt age, sex, diabetes duration, race). Results: SSDMF-corrected 1-and 4-year pt survival rates on the PAK waiting list were 98% and 85%; on the PTA waiting list, 96% and 90%. Pt survival after pa tx at 1 and 4 years in the PAK category was 95% and 85%; in the PTA category, 97% and 86%. Only 45% of pt deaths > 90 days posttx were tx-related. Multivariate mortality analysis showed that risk of death after PAK and PTA was significantly lower than risk of death while waiting for pa tx. In the PAK category, relative mortality risk after tx (vs. staying on waiting list) was 0.5 (p=0.0006); in the PTA category, relative mortality risk was 0.5 (p=0.02). Earlier studies have shown that significant bone loss occurs within 3 months following liver transplantation. Despite this, there is no data to suggest this bone loss can be prevented with therapeutic intervention.METHODS: The aim of the study was to conduct a 12 month, double blinded randomised placebo-controlled trial of zoledronic acid 4 mg, given within 7 days after liver transplantation, and again at months 1, 3, 6 and 9 post-transplant. All patients received calcium carbonate 600 mg and ergocalciferol 1000U daily. We present here the result of the interim analysis of the primary end-point, the 3 month BMD of hip and lumbar spine (LS). BMD was measured on a Lunar (Prodigy) densitometer and the data (g/cm²) was analysed by repeated measures ANOVA. Data is mean ± SEM. RESULTS: The 2 treatment groups (n=24, 21) were well balanced with respect to age, sex, underlying disease, baseline BMD and baseline 25 vit D levels. Baseline BMD levels (and mean T scores) in males and females, respectively, were: LS 1.12 ± 0.03 g/cm² (-0.9 SD); 1.01 ± 0.04 g/cm² (-1.6 SD); neck of femur (NOF) 0.95 ± 0.03 g/cm² (-0.8 SD); 0.81 ± 0.04 g/cm² (-1.3 SD); total hip 1.00 ± 0.02 g/cm² (-0.6 SD); 0.85 ± 0.04 g/cm² . At all sites the placebo group lost bone density at 3 months, ranging from 2.8% in the LS to 8.0% in the trochanter (Fig 1) . This loss was not seen at any site in patients treated with zoledronic acid. The difference between the 2 groups was highly significant for all hip parameters (total hip and Ward's p<0.0001, NOF p=0.002; trochanter p=0.02) and close to significance in LS (p=0.09). In addition, Zolendronate prevented an increase in the urinary bone resorption marker DPD/Cr at the one month time point. CONCLUSION: Intravenous zoledronic acid at the time of transplant and 1 month post-transplant prevents the acute bone loss associated with liver transplantation.

To determine the outcome of RTx in patients with SLE, and predictors of graft and patient survival. Methods: We studied all SLE patients who received RTx at our institution from 1991 to 2003. Primary endpoints were graft loss and patient death. Secondary endpoint was recurrence of lupus nephritis (RLN) in the allograft. Results: 47 patients with a mean age of 34.6±11.6 yrs received 49 RTx. Mean duration of SLE prior to RTx was 11.8 years, with a median of 31 months on dialysis. 36 recipients were female and 11 were male. 32 of 49 grafts (65%) were cadaveric (CRT). In addition to prednisone, 20 received cyclosporine (CSA) + azathioprine (AZA), and 27 tacrolimus (FK) + mycophenolate mofetil (MMF). 10 patients had delayed graft function (DGF) . Graft survival at 1 and 5 years was 87% and 66% and patient survival at 1 and 5 years was 96% and 85%, respectively. Infections accounted for 5 of 6 patient deaths. Of 16 graft losses, patient death and medical noncompliance accounted for 4 of each. DGF was associated with higher likelihood of overall graft loss (p=0.003), and death censored graft loss (p=0.004). There was no difference in graft survival in the FK/MMF compared to CSA/AZA group. 6/20 recipients died: 2 from the biliary complications (4th mo, 4th yr) and 4 from causes unrelated to the grafts (perforated bowel 2nd mo, MI 2nd yr, noncompliance 3rd yr, trauma 3rd yr). CONCLUSIONS: This series of CNHBD LTXs is among the largest published and provides long-term results about older CNHBDs. Both older and younger CNHBDs can offer safe donor pool expansion and acceptable long-term outcomes. These recipients of older CNHBD livers have not developed biliary complications. Donor age >50 should not serve as an absolute contraindication to CNHBD LTX.

Introduction: Despite the advent of living donor liver transplantation (LDLT), the number of liver transplantations remains limited. Current guidelines indicate that donors (LD) should have a body mass index (BMI) <30, despite lack of evidence that BMI correlates with steatosis or outcome. Obesity is an epidemic; locating nonobese LD may become more difficult. Hypothesis: Selected donors with a 40>BMI>30 undergo LDLT without an increased the rate of serious complications. Methods: 68 LD with normal LFT's and without significant comorbidities underwent LDLT from 4/99 to 8/03. Data on postoperative complications in LD and recipients was collected. Postoperative complications for LD were divided into 3 groups: 1) minor complications occurring more often in obese patients (wound infection, pneumonia, and hernia); 2) other minor complications occurring at equal rates in obese and non-obese patients (fever); and 3) major complications (biliary leak, biliary stricture, portal vein thrombosis, bleeding, hepatic dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia). Complication rates for LD with BMI>30 and BMI<30 were compared. Results: 68 LDLT'S were performed; 65 LD had right lobectomies, and 3 LD had leftsided procedures. 16 LD had BMI>30 and 52 had BMI<30. Major complications, as defined above, occurred in 17% of LD with BMI<30 and 6% of LD with BMI>30 (p=0.43).Rates of wound infection and hernia increased with BMI. 19% of LD with BMI<30 and 25% of LD with BMI>30 had incisional hernias (p=0.73); 3% of LD with BMI<30 and 31% of LD with BMI>30 had wound infections (p=0.006) In both groups, 13% of patients had other minor complications. No LD died. Mortality rates were 0% for recipients with livers from LD with BMI>30 and 21% for recipients with livers from LD with BMI<30, at 0.25-4.6 yrs of follow-up (p=0.055). Of 6 LD with preoperative liver biopsies, 1 had a BMI>30. No patients were excluded based on biopsy. Two morbidly obese LD (BMI>40) successfully donated livers, with a 0% mortality and a 0% serious complication rate. Conclusions: LD with BMI>30 do not experience a significantly different rate of serious complications when serving as LDLT donors. There is a significantly increased rate of wound infections, known to be associated with obesity and treatable. Updating current guidelines to include selected LD with BMI>30 has the potential to increase the donor pool, without a marked increase in risk. The value of a liver biopsy looking for steatosis requires evaluation.
back_matter.section: Abstract# 1513 OBESE DONORS FOR LDLT DO NOT HAVE AN INCREASED RATE OF SERIOUS POSTOPERATIVE COMPLICATIONS.

back_matter.text: Seiichiro Shishido, 1 Hiroyuki Satoh, 1 Hiroshi Asanuma, 1 Hiroshi Hataya, 1 Masahiro Ikeda, 1 Akira Hasegawa. 2 1 Urology and Kidney Transplantation, Tokyo Metropolitan Kiyose Children's Hospital, Kiyose, Tokyo, Japan; 2 Nephrology, Toho University, Ohmori, Tokyo, Japan. Background. Due to a severe shortage of suitable cadaveric allografts for children awaiting kidney transplants, we have performed a series of ABO-incompatible living kidney transplantations (LKT) at our institution. It is generally believe that splenectomy is an essential procedure in preventing acute vascular rejection. However, young recipients with splenectomy are at greater risk of serious bacterial infections posttransplant.Methods. Twenty-three pediatric patients underwent ABO-incompatible LKT between July 1989 and April 2003. The mean age at transplantation was 10.7 ± 4.2 years (range 5.8-17.8 years), with 19 males and 4 females. The donor to recipient ABO blood antigen incompatibility was as follows: A1→ → → → →O, 7 patients; B→ → → → →O, 6 patients; A1B→ → → → →B, 5 patients, A1→ → → → →B, 3 patients, and A1B → → → → →A, 2, patient. All patients received three or four sessions of plasmapheresis and/or immunoadsorption to remove the anti-A and/or anti-B antibodies before transplantation. Immunosuppression initially consisted of cyclosporine, methylprednisolone, cyclophosphamide/MMF, and antilymphocyte globulin. Splenectomy was performed on all recipients at the time of transplantation. In addition to pretransplant pneumococcal vaccine, penicillin prophylaxis was given to patients less than 10 years of age to prevent posttransplant pneumococcal infection. Results. The patients were followed for 8 to 170 months with a mean follow-up of 78 months. Of 23 patients, 8 recipients (35%) had 11 infectious complications after surgery. One patient developed Klebsiella pneumoniae sepsis at 6 weeks posttransplant, which was treated successfully with antibiotics. Urinary tract infection was also occurred in 2 patients. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection was the most frequent infection and occurred in 4 patients (17%). However, no patient had a serious tissue-invasive CMV disease. Herpes zoster infection occurred in two patients and successfully treated with acyclovir. One patient lost his graft because of uncontrolled delayed hyperacute rejection, while the actuarial 1-year, 5-year and 10-year graft survival rates are 96% 91%, and 91%, respectively. Conclusion. Infectious complications in ABO-incompatible kidney transplantation in children are few and, if any, not severe. Pneumococcal vaccine and the use of longterm penicillin prophylaxis may be effective to prevent pneumococcal infection for young recipients with ABO-incompatible kidney allografts. Background: Chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) is the major barrier to long-term graft survival. Increased potency of immunosuppressive therapy has successfully reduced the incidence of acute rejection but has resulted in a higher incidence of viral infections. Viral disease, particularly CMV, has been associated with chronic allograft nephropathy and recent evidence suggests a potential role of subclinical viral infection. Methods: We performed a retrospective case-control study to evaluate for the presence of herpesvirus DNA in renal allografts with CAN. Cases were pediatric renal transplant recipients who had been diagnosed with CAN from 1999 to 2002 based on both clinical and histologic criteria. Controls were patients without CAN who were matched by age and time post-transplant. Real-time quantitative PCR was used to evaluate the viral load of EBV, CMV, HHV-6, and HHV-7. Results: Five cases and 10 controls were available for analysis. The patient characteristics of cases and controls were similar with respect to age (mean: 14 yrs vs. 16 yrs), time post-transplant (mean: 16 months vs. 20 months), immunosuppression (CSA/MMF/pred: 4/5 vs. 6/10), and CMV and EBV donor and recipient status (CMV D+/R-: 3/5 vs. 6/10 and EBV D+/R-: 4/5 vs. 7/10). The mean creatinine was 2.6 mg/dl in cases and 1.6 mg/dl in controls. None of the patients had clinical evidence of herpesvirus disease. Herpesvirus DNA was detected in 4/5 cases compared to 1/10 controls (p<0.001). EBV was the most common virus detected 4/5 cases. More than one herpesvirus was detected in 3/5 cases of CAN.
back_matter.section: Abstract# 1521 INFECTIOUS COMPLICATIONS IN ABO-INCOMPATIBLE KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION IN CHILDREN.

However, the accuracy of chronic histological scoring is confounded by the heterogeneity of CAN development. In pediatric renal allograft recipients undergoing protocol bxs, the variability of Banff chronic scores is unknown. Purpose: Using a natural history cohort of pediatric protocol bx patients (pts), we sought to: 1. Define the incidence of bx regression error during CAN surveillance; 2. Determine if 2 sequential bxs can reliably predict a pattern of CAN development. Methods: Percutaneous bxs were performed using ultrasound and a 16gauge needle (2 cores). Tissues were stained with Masson's trichrome. Bxs were evaluated (Banff criteria) by a renal pathologist. Only bxs conforming to Banff specimen adequacy standards were included. Chronic scores and CAN grades were recorded longitudinally and sequential bxs were classified as having no progression, progression or regression. Results were expressed as mean ± SD. Results: We studied 149 bxs (15 donor, 92 protocol, 25 acute graft dysfunction and 17 follow-up rejection therapy) from 31 pts on P/FK/MMF (0-95 mo. post-transplant). Pts had 4.8 ± 2.1 bxs. Bxs had 19.0 ± 9.2 glomeruli and 3.0 ± 1.7 arteries. 7/31 (23%) pts with 5.7 ± 5.3 mo. follow-up did not progress, while 24/31 (77%) pts had histological progression (CAN O-I: 4.8 ± 3.5 mo.; CAN I-II: 18.0 ± 11.4 mo.; CAN O-II: 7.0 ± 4.6 mo.). However, 3/7 (43%) pts with no progression and 13/24 (54%) pts with progression had at least 1 bx in which the CAN grade transiently regressed. Because these pts received no specific therapeutic interventions for CAN, their histological regression was attributed to either sampling error or scoring error. Regression errors occurred in a total of 23/149 (15%) bxs, including 15/52 (29%) bxs formerly graded as CAN I and 8/26 (31%) bxs formerly graded as CAN II (I vs. II, p=NS). Among the bxs with sufficient follow-up, 5/7 (71%) with CAN I-O regression and 3/5 (60%) with CAN II-I regression reverted to their previous grades at the next sampling point. The percentages of individually misclassified lesions were: ci (13%), cv (14%), ct (12%), cg (2%) and mm (7%). Conclusions: More than 2 protocol bxs may be needed to establish a pattern of CAN development. We recommend that a 15% incidence of bx regression error be applied to power calculations for pediatric clinical trials using CAN as the primary end-point.The original 6-month study investigated the withdrawal of steroids and MMF from a tacrolimus triple regimen (Tac/MMF/steroids). In total 833 patients were randomised at month 3 to either the control group (Tac/MMF/steroids, n=277), the steroidwithdrawal group (Tac/MMF, n=279), or the MMF-withdrawal group (Tac/steroids, n=277). The study showed that the withdrawal of steroids at month 3 was associated with a significant reduction in total cholesterol at month 6 (-0.49 mmol/L, p<0.001), while the overall incidence of acute biopsy-proven rejection was not different between the groups (17.0%, 15.1%, and 14.8%, p=0.744). Methods: An investigator-driven follow-up of all patients whether withdrawn from the original study or not was initiated. The centres have been providing data at 1, 2, and 3 years post transplantation. The data have been entered electronically into a case record form via an internet-based system. Immune tolerance to allogeneic solid organ or bone marrow allografts remains an elusive goal of clinical transplantation. T cell tolerance can be accomplished in murine systems by simultaneously providing T cells with "signal 1" (alloantigen) while blocking "signal 2" through costimulation blockade. We have reliably used the costimulation blockade reagents CTLA4-Ig and anti-CD40L in conjunction with a nonmyeloablative bone marrow transplant to produce allogeneic transplantation tolerance in a fully MHCmismatched murine system. However, relatively large cells doses (>10x10 6 ) of bone marrow must be transplanted for this regimen to be successful. Costimulation-blockaderesistant rejection occurs consistently when smaller cell doses of bone marrow are transplanted. In this study, we investigated the contribution of NK cell alloreactivity to this costimulation-blockade-resistant rejection response. After a nonmyeloablative preparative regimen of 20mg/kg busulfan, increasing doses of Balb/C (NK1.1 -) bone marrow (0.5-, 2-, 5-, 10-, and 20x10 6 cells) were transplanted into C57BL/6 (NK1.1 + ) mice. Costimulation-blockade with CTLA4-Ig and anti-CD40L was given in the peritransplant period. In addition, in one-half of the transplanted animals, NK cells were depleted by IP injection of the depleting antibody, PK136. Animals with unmanipulated NK cells exhibited costimulation-blockade resistant rejection when transplanted with ≤ 5x10 6 donor bone marrow cells. However, animals with NK cell depletion became stably chimeric with donor marrow even when very low doses (as little as 0.5x10 6 ) were infused. The chimeric animals in both the NK replete and NK-depleted groups were tolerant to their allografts: They exhibited deletion of donor-reactive vb5 + and vb8 + CD4 + T cells and accepted Balb/C skin grafts. In contrast, animals that rejected their bone marrow grafts failed to delete the vb5/8 T cells and rejected Balb/C skin grafts. These data demonstrate the central role that NK cells play in rejection of allogeneic bone marrow and underscore the need to control NK alloreactivity during clinical transplantation.

Introduction: Multiple genes contribute to Type I diabetes, however, the principle determining genetic component in NOD mice and humans is the inheritance of mutant MHC class II β chains. Here we test the hypothesis that expression of retrovirally transduced MHC class II β chains from wild-type MHC haplotypes in bone marrow derived hematopoietic cells can be used to prevent diabetes in NOD mice. Methods: NOD mice (4-6 weeks) were conditioned with 10.25 Gy TBI, and followed within 24hrs by reconstitution with 5-Fu treated NOD bone marrow transduced with retrovirus encoding a fusion protein consisting of either I-Aβ d or I-Aβ k chain fused to GFP or GFP protein as a control. The blood glucose level and the frequency of GFP expressing cells in peripheral blood were monitored weekly. Mice were sacrificed for immunohistochemistry and Elispot at different time points after reconstitution. Results: FACS revealed that relatively stable expression of GFP is ready to detect in PBMC of mice reconstituted with I-Aβ d -GFP or I-Aβ k -GFP and control GFP transduced bone marrow cells during the 36 week follow-up period. Confocal microscopy showed that in PBMC from mice transduced with GFP, GFP expression was in the cytoplasm. In contrast, in MHC class II positive PBMC from mice transduced with I-Aβ d -GFP, GFP expression appeared solely at the cell membrane and co-localized with expression of I-Aβ d . While 79% (11/14) of mice reconstituted with hematopoietic cells transduced with GFP became diabetic, none (0/24) of the mice reconstitution with either I-Aβ d -GFP or I-Aβ k -GFP virus became diabetic by week 48 (P<0.001). Imunohistochemistry showed that islets from mice transduced with GFP showed massive T cell infiltrate and decreased production of insulin, while islets from mice transduced with either I-Aβ d -GFP or I-Aβ k -GFP virus had no visible cell infiltrate and normal levels of insulin production. ELISPOT analysis showed cells from diabetic mice transduced with GFP had vigorous production of IL-2, INF-γ and IL-4 in response to either GAD65 peptide or insulin protein. In contrast, cells from mice transduced with either I-Aβ d -GFP or I-Aβ k -GFP had very low levels of IL-2, INF-γ and IL-4 (P<0.001). Conclusion: Expression of non-susceptible MHC alleles in the hematopoietic cells is sufficient to prevent the development of functional auto-reactive T cells, insulitis and type I diabetes in NOD mice. Somatic transfer of MHC genes into autologous bone marrow using retroviral transduction represents a major new approach to re-establishing tolerance to self in Type I diabetes. Background: Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) represent a distinct subset of DC implicated in resistance to viral infection and in immune regulation. Tolerogenic properties of human and mouse pDC have been reported in vitro. Little is known regarding the in vivo properties of pDC. In this study, we have evaluated the influence of in vitro-propagated mouse bone marrow (BM)-derived pDC on T cell responses to alloantigens in vitro and in vivo. Methods:DC were propagated from normal C57BL/ 10J (B10: H2 b ) mouse BM cells in media containing 200 ng/ml human recombinant fmslike tyrosine kinase 3 ligand for 10 days. pDC were flow-sorted to > 98% purity on the basis of their surface phenotype (CD11c + B220 + CD11b -). Their costimulatory molecule expression and stimulatory capacity for allogeneic T cells (C3H; H2 k ) in mixed leukocyte reactions were compared to those of classic BM-derived myeloid DC (mDC: CD11c + B220 -CD11b + ). To assess their influence on T cell responses in vivo, C3H (H2 k ) were received 2x10 6 flow-sorted pDC or mDC intravenously from B10 (H2 b ) donors and 7 days later, splenic T cells were restimulated with B10 (donor) alloantigen. Results: Unstimulated BM-derived pDC expressed little or no surface MHC class II or classic costimulatory molecules (CD40, CD80 and CD86). On the other hand, they expressed programmed death ligand 1(PD-L1), an alternative costimulatory molecule implicated in regulation of T cell responses. These cells induced poor proliferative responses and low secretion of IFN-γ and IL-10 by allogeneic T cells. Stimulation with the Toll-like receptor 9 ligand CpG-oligodeoxynucleotide upregulated MHC class II and costimulatory molecules on pDC and markedly enhanced their stimulatory capacity for naive allogeneic T cells. However, the level of proliferation was lower than that induced by mDC. T cells from mice primed with unstimulated allogeneic pDC exhibited significantly lower proliferative response to donor alloantigens compared with those from mDC-primed mice. This hyporesponsiveness was restored by addition of exogenous recombinant IL-2. Conclusions: BM-derived pDC are immature antigen-presenting cells that can induce T cell hyporesponsiveness to alloantigen in vitro and in vivo. This finding suggests that pDC have potential for regulation of alloimmunity and promotion of tolerance induction. Background: While tolerance to islet allotransplants has been achieved in several murine systems, success of standard protocols has not followed in the autoimmune NOD strain, the model for human IDDM. We have investigated tolerance induced by anti-CD45RB in a cardiac allotransplant model in the NOD background to focus on aspects of tolerance resistance in the absence of recurrent autoimmunity. Comparison to the NOR strain (88% genetic identity to NOD) permits us to elucidate the mechanisms underlying tolerance resistance in the autoimmune background. Methods: Cardiac allografts from C3H mice were transplanted to either pre-diabetic (<12 wks) NOD mice or diabetes resistant NOR mice. Recipients were untreated or treated with anti-CD45RB mAb (100ug ip days 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7). To investigate the effect of anti-CD45RB, extensive immunophenotyping of T cells, B Cells, and professional APC subsets was performed following exposure of animals to alloantigen in the presence or absence of anti-CD45RB. Proliferation of mitogen stimulated T cells from both strains was performed utilizing CFSE by standard protocols. Results: Cardiac allografts were rejected acutely with a mean survival time (MST) of 9.2 days in untreated NOD mice (n=6). In NOD mice treated with anti-CD45RB, only a minimal prolongation of graft survival was noted (MST=24.3d, n=6). However, NOR mice demonstrated a significant prolongation in graft survival (MST>63.1d, n=8). In vitro studies showed that the NOR strain shares the similar hypoproliferative phenotype associated with decreased AICD, suggesting that clearance of alloreactive specificities may contribute to tolerance induction. Immunophenotyping of the NOD strain has revealed a number of alterations in B cell surface markers following contact with CD45RB and alloantigen including downregulation in CD19 and upregulation in CD54. Conclusions: Short-term administration of anti-CD45RB mAb significantly prolongs allograft survival in diabetes resistant NOR mice as compared to the autoimmune prone NOD strain. However, donor specific tolerance could not be induced in either strain suggesting that graft prolongation is separable from tolerance induction. The proliferative dysfunction of T cells may account for the resistance to long-term tolerance induction as this feature is shared with both NOD and NOR. Introduction: The chemokine receptor CXCR3 plays an important role in recruiting Tcells into allografts. Accordingly, blocking the interaction between CXCR3 and its ligands prolongs graft survival. We examined the mechanisms of CXCR3 mediated Tcell activation Methods: T-cell lines stably transfected with CXCR3 were stimulated with its cognate ligands Mig, IP-10, and I-TAC. After cell stimulation, cells were lysed, with whole cell lysates subjected to Western blot analysis with phosphotyrosine specific antibodies. Results: Stimulation of CXCR3 transfected T-cells induced strong tyrosine phosphorylation of the critical T-cell signaling molecules Lck, ZAP-70, and LAT. All molecules were tyrosine-phosphorylated within minutes after cell stimulation. Phosphorylation occurred at tyrosine residues 171 and 191 in LAT and tyrosine residue 319 in ZAP-70, residues which are also phosphorylated in TCR mediated signaling. Similar results were seen whether cells were stimulated with Mig, IP-10, or I-TAC. In addition, treatment of cells with the Syk/ZAP-70 inhibitor piceatannol impaired CXCR3 mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of ZAP-70 and LAT in a dose dependent fashion. In cross talk experiments, stimulating cells first through the TCR inhibited CXCR3 mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of Lck, ZAP-70, and LAT; similarly, stimulation of cells first through CXCR3 attenuated TCR mediated protein tyrosine phosphorylation.
