back_matter.text: The increased tyrosine phosphorylation of Lck, ZAP-70, and LAT after CXCR3-ligand interactions strongly implicates these molecules as having an important role in CXCR3 mediated signaling. The crosstalk results indicate that these receptors share common signaling pathways and suggest that in vivo prior stimulation of one receptor may attenuate the function of the other receptor. This could be important in designing therapeutic strategies to prevent graft rejection that target these receptors on T-cells; for example, because CXCR3 and TCR share signaling pathways, one drug could be used to block the function of both receptors in turn reducing drug toxicity associated with using more than one immunosuppressant to block each receptor individually. Although it is well established that both CD4 and CD8 T cells are involved in the rejection of grafts mismatched for minor histocompatibility antigens, the specific mechanisms of cooperation between the two populations are not well defined. This is due in part to technical limitations that prevent the direct monitoring of graft-specific T cells during the rejection process. To address this, we have used a mouse model system in which we track, in vivo, the behavior of T cell receptor (TCR)-transgenic chicken ovalbumin (OVA)-specific CD4 and CD8 T cells in response to skin grafts mismatched for a single foreign "minor" antigen, OVA. Donor tail skin is obtained from transgenic mice that express OVA under the control of chicken beta-actin promoter on the surface of most cells (Act-mOVA). RESULTS: Naive OT-I TCR transgenic CD8 T cells were intravenously injected alone or together with naïve OT-II TCR-transgenic CD4 T cells into B6 recipients. A group of recipients were left uninjected as controls. Maximal rejection of Act-mOVA tail skin grafts was dependent on the presence of both OT-I and OT-II cells. Control B6 isografts were accepted indefinitely. OT-I and OT-II cells were activated in draining lymph nodes (DLN) and not spleens as evidenced by CD69 expression. The migration and accumulation of OT-I cells in spleens and grafts occurred subsequent to their activation and proliferation in DLN. OT-II cells had several measurable effects on OT-I cells. First, they enhanced the accumulation of OT-I cells within skin grafts and migration of OT-I cells specifically to the skin as measured by enhanced expression of fructosylated form of PSGL-1. This was completely blocked in the absence of CD154 expression on OT-II cells. Second, they enhanced the cytotoxicity of OT-I as measured by in vitro chromium release assay and in vivo killing of OVA expressing cells. This effect was independent of CD154 expression on OT-II cells but may be related to IL-12 production by an activated DC. Thirdly, they enhance the generation of memory cells as evidenced by persistence and effector function in vivo. This effect was also independent of CD154 expression on OT-II cells. CONCLUSION: Using a CD154-dependent mechanism, graft-specific CD4 T cells facilitate graft-specific CD8 T cell migration and graft infiltration. Using a CD154independent mechanism, graft-specific CD4 T cells enhance CD8 T cell cytotoxicity and generation of memory cells. Allograft outcome, rejection or tolerance, often depends on the balance between cytopathic and regulatory T cells. We previously reported that treatment with rapamycin and costimulation blockade resulted in massive apoptosis of alloreactive T cells and produced stable skin allograft tolerance. In contrast, treatment with cyclosporine plus costimulation blockade abolished T cell apoptosis, as well as tolerance induction. In this study we further investigated the effects of these two immunosuppressive drugs on the immunosuppressive function of regulatory T cells. We used an adoptive transfer skin allograft model and combined donor specific transfusion (DST) plus anti-CD154 treatment, a tolerizing protocol known to enhance the immunosuppressive effect of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells in an alloantigenspecific manner. Sorted CD4+CD25+ T cells from nave or DST plus anti-CD154 with or without rapamycin or cyclosporine treated C57BL/6 hosts were adoptively transferred into syngeneic RAG1 (-/-) hosts together with the same number of nave CD25-T cells before transplantation with DBA/2 skin allografts. For in vitro study of regulatory T cells, T cell proliferation in mixed lymphocyte reaction (MLR) was assayed. In accord with our previous studies, CD4+CD25+ T cells from DST plus anti-CD154 treated, but not from nave, hosts were capable of delaying skin allografts rejection in this model. Interestingly, the addition of cyclosporine abolished the DST plus anti-CD154 effect, since CD4+CD25+ T cells harvested from the hosts treated with adjunctive cyclosporine could not significantly delay skin allograft rejection. In contrast, the addition of rapamycin to the basic regimen further enhanced the immunoregulatory function of CD4+CD25+ T cells, as all skin allograft survived more than 40 days. The addition of cyclosporine to the basic regimen also abrogated the suppressive effect of CD4+CD25+ T cells as compared to CD4+CD25+ T cells from hosts treated with DST plus anti-CD154 as assessed in a mixed lymphocyte reaction. In this study, we found that the addition of cyclosporine abrogated, while addition of rapamycin enhanced, the tolerizing effect of DST plus anti-CD154 treatment to enhance the immunosuppressive effect of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells, which suggests an important difference in mode of action of these two immunosuppressive drugs. Moreover, these data indicate that regimens that promote tolerance must block alloaggressive, but spare or strengthen, immunoregulatory components of the allograft response. Indirect recognition of donor-derived mHAg has been shown to play an important role in the targeting of grafts for destruction by CD8+ T cells. Naive T cell activation is thought to depend on the recognition of Ag/MHC complexes on professional APC such as DC within the draining lymph nodes. Recipient APC that pick up donor mHAg may then present the Ag to alloreactive CD8+ T cells; however, Ag may also be presented to the T cells by donor-derived APC carried within the graft if there is sharing of class I alleles between the donor and host. Investigations of CD8+ alloreactivity against mHAg have been complicated because lymphoid populations are heterogeneous in specificity and the important graft target Ag are poorly understood. We developed a model of skin allograft rejection that relies on the adoptive transfer of OT-I TCRtransgenic CD8+ T cells (specific for OVAp SIINFEKL in the context of Kb) into recipient mice and the transplantation of skin from either MHC identical or MHC mismatched mice that carry a transgene for a transmembrane form of OVA protein. Using wild-type B6 (Kb+) or mutant bm8 (Kb-) graft recipient mice, and either B6-OVA (Kb+) or BALB/ c-OVA (Kb-) donors, it was determined that both donor and recipient APC were competent to induce CFSE dye-dilution and a 5 fold clonal expansion of the OVAreactive OT-I CD8+ T cells in the graft tissue. In contrast, OT-1 CD8+ T cell enrichment within allograft tissue proved to be highly dependant on the presence of Kb on both donor and recipient cells. OT-I T cells reached 80% of total infiltrating CD8+ T cells when mHAg could be presented by both donor and recipient cells, whereas enrichment decreased to only 17% when only recipient APC could present the mHAg and 7% when only donor-derived Kb was available. To determine whether the decrease in OT-I enrichment observed in MHC-mismatched BALB/c-OVA allografts was due to competition with other endogenous H-2d reactive CD8+ T cells or the lack of a Kb molecule on the donor cells, we used (BALB/c x B6) F1 OVA donors. The OT-I T cells found in the F1 OVA graft tissue represented 55% of the total CD8+ T cells, a frequency more than twice that observed in the mismatched BALB/c-OVA grafts. Thus, the crosspresentation of mHAg by host APC can be an important stimulus for the clonal expansion of mHAg-specific CD8+ T cells within the draining lymph nodes. Nevertheless, class I MHC matching between donor and host can promote graft infiltration and the retention of mHAg-reactive CD8+ T cells. Work supported by NIH PO1 AI50162.

Background: Urine cytology has been suggested as a simple technique to screen kidney transplant patients for BK virus (BKV) activation. Virus infected 'decoy cells' can be always found in all patients with histologic nephropathy, and in up to 29% of stable transplant recipients. We have sought to determine whether using PCR as the primary screening technique would offer significant advantages over urine cytology Design: 100 urine samples from 62 kidney transplant patients were examined for decoy cells by light microscopy. BK and JC virus load was assessed in aliquots of the same samples by quantitative real time PCR using the Roche LightCycler. Results: Definite decoy cells were seen in 8% and possible decoy cells in 5% of samples. Quantitative PCR showed BKV DNA in all the preceding samples, and in additional 18% of samples in which no decoy cells could be detected. BKV genomic copy number in the positive samples varied from <200 to 1.49E+09 copies/ml. Thus, the use of decoy cells as a marker of polyomavirus viruria has a sensitivity of 41.9% and negative predictive value of 82.8%. The specificity and positive predictive value are 100%. False negative results occurred in samples with suboptimal cellularity, vaginal contamination, and a low viral load. One patient with a false negative urine cytology developed BKV nephropathy on follow up. Background and Aims: Diagnosis of BK nephropathy (BKN) in renal transplants is frequently followed by loss of function (LOF). Reduction of immunosuppression (IS) remains the central treatment and repeated graft biopsy is considered the "gold standard" for determining persistence of BKN. We examined the factors contributing to progressive LOF in biopsy-proven BKN managed by reduced IS alone. Methods: Clinical, laboratory and histologic data was reviewed for 37 renal allograft recipients with biopsy-proven BKN, managed by reduced IS (without antiviral therapy) with at least 1 year of follow-up. Follow-up biopsies were carried out on 32 of 37 cases and 6 grafts were lost during the first year post-diagnosis. GFR at diagnosis of BKN and 1 year later was estimated by modified MDRD formula. The cases were subdivided into those with stable GFR (< 10% loss from diagnosis to 1 year) and those with progressive LOF (≥ 10% loss). Results: Results (see table) are shown as mean ± SD. Conclusions: (a) Almost 50% of the BKN cases managed by reduced IS alone had progressive LOF during the first year following diagnosis. (b) Diagnosis later posttransplantation and degree of chronic tubulointerstitial injury at the time of diagnosis were associated with progressive LOF. (c) Increased tubulointerstitial injury during the first year following BKN diagnosis was also observed in grafts with stable GFR. (d) Absence of BKV on follow-up biopsy did not guarantee stable graft function. Polyoma BK virus-associated nephritis (BKV-N) is a relevant cause of reduced renal allograft survival. As demonstrated for other viral infections relevant to transplantation, failure to mount a protective immune response may be a central event in the development of BKV-active infection and the related pathology. In order to assess BKV-specific cellular immunity, we retrospectively analysed by ELISPOT assay the frequency of IFNγ-secreting cells after stimulation with dendritic cells pulsed with inactivated BKV in pediatric kidney recipients with or without BKV infection/reactivation, as compared with healthy controls. While healthy BKV-seronegative individuals (n=2) did not show IFNγ secretion in response to the virus, the mean frequency of cytokineproducing cells in seropositive controls (n=7) was 151/10 6 cells (range 30-430).Patients with BKV-active infection and good renal function (n=6; viruria+/viremia-) had a mean BKV-specific lymphocyte frequency 2-log lower than healthy controls (5.5/10 6 cells; range: 0-9), and in the same range as KTx recipients seropositive for BKV in the absence of active infection (n=6; viruria-/viremia-; frequency: 4/10 6 cells; range: 0-9). Conversely, patients with BKV-N (n=4; viruria+/viremia+) revealed undetectable levels of BKV-specific cells. However, upon repeated stimulations in vitro with the antigen, in all 4 patients a measurable frequency of specific T cells was obtained, which resulted in the expansion of BKV-specific cytotoxic T cell lines. Indeed, one patient from the latter cohort treated with immunosuppression reduction, and evaluated prospectively, showed emergence of specific immunity, with IFNγ production in the same range as healthy seropositive controls. In conclusion, our preliminary data suggest that: i) in the presence of immunosuppressive drugs, the capacity to develop a primary immune response or expand memory BKV-specific lymphocytes upon virus infection/reactivation is hampered; ii) the degree of immune deficiency, likely coupled with the extent of viral load, may determine the progression to graft damage; iii) immunosuppression reduction allows the emergence of protective BKV-specific immunity also in patients with deeply defective immune response. Background: Hypoxia and accumulation of metabolic wastes during preservation result in vascular endothelial cell (VEC) injury and impairment of tissue microcirculation, followed by parenchymal cell damage during ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury. We have shown that carbon monoxide (CO) provides protection against cold I/R injury by inhibiting apoptosis, reducing proinflammatory mediators, and maintaining graft blood flow. This study examined roles of inhaled CO during I/R injury in activating hypoxia inducible factor (HIF-1α) and promoting repair mechanisms, including VEGF, VEGF receptors, HO-1 and iNOS. Methods: A Lewis rat kidney graft, preserved in UW at 4 o C for 24 hrs, was orthotopically transplanted into binephrectomized syngeneic rats. Recipients were maintained in room air or exposed to CO (250 ppm) for 1 hr before and 24 hrs after transplant and sacrificed 1, 3, 6, and 24 hrs. Separate groups of animals were followed to assess long term kidney function and survival. Results: At 1 hr after reperfusion, F-Actin and CD31 (PECAM) expression on podocytes, tubular epithelial cells (TEC), and VEC was lost in AIR-exposed animals, indicating significant damages to kidney grafts. Lack of nephrin stain on podocytes or cadherin on TEC further confirmed the significant I/R injury in control group. In contrast, CO-treated animals showed nearly normal stain patterns, indicating well-preserved kidney graft structure. HIF-1α was upregulated on glomeruli of CO-exposed, but not AIR-treated animals as early as 1 hr after reperfusion. VEGF and VEGF receptors, FLK1 and neuropilin, were upregulated on VEC and TEC of CO-exposed, but not AIR-exposed kidney grafts at 1 hr and continuously for 24 hrs after reperfusion. CO exposure also resulted in lower HO-1, iNOS, and endotelin 1 expression during 24 hrs after transplant compared to controls. These early protection and repair promotion by CO associated with improved long-term kidney function. CO-treated animals had significantly lower creatinine levels (2.2±0.2 vs 6.2±2.8 mg/dl) and higher creatinine clearance (0.18±0.05 vs 0.04±0.03 ml/min) than controls at 24d after transplantation and improved survival. Conclusions:

The study demonstrates that the protective effect of CO involves HIF/VEGF and VEGF receptor upregulation early after transplant. The impact of these early protective changes reflect on the better long term function and survival of CO-exposed animals. Introduction-Treatments following warm ischemia (WI) accelerating cellular recovery could have major impact on increasing kidneys procured from non-heartbeating donors. Warm perfusion (32°C) was employed to deliver growth factors (fibroblast growth factor (FGF)-1 and 2) to kidneys damaged by 2hrs WI. Sequelae determining pro-or anti-apoptotic pathways were assessed using a TUNEL assay. Junctional integrity protein, ZO-1 was used to determine recovery of cytoskeletal integrity. Upregulation of proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) was used as a marker for DNA repair and recovery of synthetic functions. Ability to repair the injury following 2-hrs of WI was correlated with clinical outcomes. Methods-Using a canine autotransplant model, kidneys were subjected to 2 hrs of WI and divided into 4 groups: Group 1 (n=2) 2 hrs WI, followed by immediate reimplantation Group 2 (n=2) 2 hrs WI, 24 hrs hypothermic machine perfusion (4°C) and reimplantation Group 3 (n=2) 2 hrs WI, 24 hrs warm perfusion without growth factor (32°C) and reimplantation Group 4(n=4) 2 hrs WI, 24 hrs warm perfusion plus growth factors (32°C) and reimplantation Results-TUNEL assay-Following reimplantation, the number of TUNEL stained cells in Group 2 and 3 were 50 and 20% respectively. In Group 4, the kidneys were TUNEL negative following 24-hrs of perfusion and reperfusion. ZO-1-Kidneys in Group 2 demonstrated intense positive staining for ZO-1 accompanied by a degree of disintegration. Kidneys that were warm perfused with growth factors (Group 4) normalized ZO-1 expression in a time dependent fashion during warm perfusion. Normalization was impaired in the absence of FGF(s). PCNA-WI damaged kidneys in Group 2 resulted in 2% PCNA staining. In contrast, in kidneys in Group 4 an upregulation of PCNA expression was observed with >80% of the cells staining positive. Absence of FGF(s) impaired PCNA expression. Function-FGFs induced up-regulation of PCNA, accompanied by the down-regulation of ZO-1 that occurred in Group 4 kidneys was found to correlate with outcomes posttransplantation. Reimplantation of "repaired" kidneys resulted in life-sustaining function. Reimplantation in Groups 1,2 or 3 resulted in non-viable kidneys. Conclusion-Metabolism was sufficiently restored to support upregulation of cellular processes with potential to modulate both injury and repair proteins in WI kidneys. Results suggest that administration of FGF(s) triggers pathways for new synthesis leading to cellular recovery rather than activation of the apoptotic pathway.

back_matter.text: To expand the potential donor pool, marginal donors are often utilized. The damage of marginal-sized grafts is common. Development of novel pharmaceutical therapy to rescue small-for-size liver grafts is always important.
The aim of the study is to probe into the protective mechanism of FTY720 in a rat liver transplantation model using small-for-size graft by the investigation of cell survival and apoptosis pathways.

A rat orthotopic liver transplantation model using 40% of liver grafts was applied. In the FTY720 treatment group, FTY720 was administrated by iv injection (1mg/kg) (1) at 20 minutes before graft harvesting in the donor, and (2) immediately before liver out in the recipient and (3) immediately after reperfusion in the recipient. 7-day survival rate was compared. Liver tissues were sampled at 6 and 24 hours after reperfusion for morphological examination (hepatic ultrastructure), apoptotic nuclei staining (TUNEL), and intragraft gene detection for cell survival (Akt) and apoptosis (Caspase) signaling pathways by Western blot and immunostaining. Blood samples were analyzed for liver function.

The 7-day graft survival rates in the FTY720 group were significantly improved compared to the control group (100% (6/6) vs 40% (4/10), p=0.034). FTY720 significantly reduced serum ALT and AST levels at 24 hours after liver transplantation The cell survival signaling Akt pathway was significantly activated at ser 473 after FTY720 treatment by phosphorylation of GSK-3, Bad and FKHR in FTY720 group at 6 hours and 24 hours after liver transplantation. The cleaved Caspase 3, 7 and 9 were down regulated accompanied with less apoptotic nuclei after FTY720 treatment. The anti-apoptotic gene A20 was up-regulated and iNOS was down-regulated at 6 and 24 hours after reperfusion in FTY720 groups. Hepatic ultrastructure was well maintained in FTY720 group compared to the control group with disruption of hepatic sinusoids.

FTY 720 attenuates small-for-size liver graft injury by significant activation of cell survival signaling pathway. Introduction: A precise prediction of non-immune injury, such as severe ischemia reperfusion (IR), and its differentiation from acute kidney rejection and calcineurin inhibitor toxicity remains difficult. ¹H-NMR quantitative metabonomics was used to establish metabolic markers of mild and severe IR injury in a rat kidney transplant model. Methods: Male Lewis rats were used for syngeneic kidney transplantation. Donor kidneys were cold stored for various times (24 and 42 hours) (CI) followed by transplantation and organ harvest on day 1 (TX 24/24; TX 42/24); n= 6 each group). Donor kidneys with cold storage only (CI 24; CI 42; n=6 each group) as well as native kidneys served as controls. Kidney and blood samples were frozen, extracted using acid/lipid extraction procedure and analyzed by ¹H-MRS with a Bruker 500 Avance system. Results: Over 50 endogenous metabolites were quantified from each kidney and blood extract. Logistic regression analysis distinguished two IR renal tissue markers, polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) and allantoin (a novel marker of oxidative stress and endproduct of the xanthine pathway). Two markers, trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO) and allantoin were sensitive markers for the severity of IR injury in the blood. Decreased PUFA and increased TMAO concentrations are markers of non-specific renal injury and were seen previously with cyclosporine toxicity. However, the high correlation with elevated allantoin concentrations in all reperfusion study groups allowed discrimination of the severity of renal IR injury. Allantoin was seen only after reperfusion (control 0.02±0.03 µmol/mL, TX24 1.13±0.22, and TX42 1.89±0.38). The correlation coefficient for allantoin concentration was excellent for cold ischemia time (r=0.96) and for graft function (r=0.97).Conclusion: MRS based metabolic profiling allowed to identify and quantify the extent of IR injury (allantoin) and correlation of medullary damage (TMAO). In the future, this high correlation between different surrogate markers may distinguish pathologic processes such as early rejection and severe IR injury.Intro.: Despite the increase of diabetes in minority populations, access and outcomes for pancreas transplantation remains controversial. The purpose of our study was to assess the impact of ethnicity of access to transplantation and evaluate long term outcomes. Methods: All patients who were wait listed and underwent SPK, PAK or PTA in the US between 1990 and 2001 were compared by race/ethnicity. A separate Kaplan Meir and multivariate analysis was performed to evaluate 5 year graft survival rates by ethnicity. Results: Table 1 -Although improvements in outcomes were seen for all forms of pancreas transplants, no ethnic differences were seen for PAK or PTA. SPK survival rates are summarized in Table 2 . Conclusion: Important disparities persist for Type 1 diabetic minority patients with or without CKD, despite the increase of Type 1 diabetes in these populations. No significant outcome differences exist between blacks and whites although outcomes for blacks decreased over time and Hispanics had the highest graft survival rates. More efforts are needed to increase pancreas transplantation in minority and underserved populations. Introduction. The waiting time for kidney transplantation (TX) in those without an ABO-compatible (ABOc) donor can exceed five years at an approximate cost of $60,000/ yr for dialysis. ABO-incompatible (ABOi) living-donor kidney transplant (LDKT) is thus an increasingly viable option to increase access to KT, yet it requires more therapy and is considered more costly than ABOc TX. This study examines the increased cost and resource utilization associated with ABOi-KT. Methods. One-year graft survival, resource utilization and costs pre-op and for the first 90 days post-op were compared retrospectively in ABOi vs. ABOc transplants. ABOi patients underwent pre-TX conditioning with plasmapheresis, splenectomy on day of TX, and surveillance biopsies on days 3, 7, 14. Immunosuppression was similar in the two groups. Resource utilization (surgical procedures, hospitalizations, hospital days, complications, etc.) was compared using the Mann-Whitney rank sum test. Cost data was obtained from an institutional cost data center. Results. One-year graft survival was 94% for ABOi vs. 96% for ABOc transplants. During this time, the surgical morbidity rate was 65.9% for ABOi vs. 41.5% for ABOc individuals. There was no significant difference between the number of hospital admissions, medical and total complications, pre-and post-op visits, and radiologic procedures. Resource utilization was significantly higher for ABOi TX in several categories (Table) . The increase in cost was more than $50,000/patient of which 80% was post-TX due to increased surveillance and hospitalizations. Conclusion. ABOi-LDKT acheives shortterm graft survival similar to ABOc KT. Despite the increased resource utilization, morbidity, and cost, ABOi TX compares well to the annual cost for dialysis and decreases wait-time associated morbidity. Waiting list management is becoming increasingly challenging with extended waiting times and consequently elevated numbers of patients on the list. Resources to properly evaluate and follow potential recipients on the waiting list are often limited, yet tracking the progress of these patients is increasingly important. In the attempt to individualize high risk patients who might benefit from early re-evaluation while on the waiting list, we analyzed records of patients from the USRDS database who began their first wait list period from 1995-2000. A multivariate Cox model was constructed for the primary endpoint of patient death, censored at the time of transplant. Cardiac death and death after transplant were secondary endpoints in the analysis. The combination of significant patient risk factors was used to generate a risk score applicable at the time of wait listing. The factors of highest significance included patient age, primary diagnosis, prior cardiac events, race, length of time on dialysis, and BMI. We derived the risk scores from a randomly selected sample constituting 2/3 rds of available records and tested results on the remaining cohort. Outcomes were consistent in the model and test groups, and we observed a significant strong association between the risk score and patient survival. With the lowest 70% risk scores as reference, the relative risk of patients in the 70-79 th percentile was 2.5, 80-89 th percentile 3.0, 90-94 th percentile 3.9, and 95-100 th percentile 4.9.The identification of high risk patients on the waiting list would provide valuable information to centers and allow them to discriminate follow up resources appropriately. With a growing volume of wait list candidates, the ability to understand important risk factors and manage patients accordingly is a critical component of pre-transplant care and waiting list management. Body: Background: FTY720, a novel immunomodulator, has been shown to be both safe and efficacious for de novo renal transplants. Preliminary economic studies have also demonstrated important potential economic benefit for FTY720 in combination with cyclosporine (CsA) in renal transplantation. Methods: We conducted an economic analysis based on clinical results from two phase 2 studies comparing FTY720 and mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in combination with CsA and steroids. In these studies, patients receiving FTY720 0.25-5 mg/day in combination with full or reduced dose CsA + steroids for 3-months (n=167) or 12months (n=222) post-transplant were compared with a comparator arm receiving MMF 2 g/day + full dose CsA + steroids. Principal clinical outcomes, i.e. acute rejection, graft loss and death were used to populate an economic decision model. Total direct medical costs during the first year post-transplant included costs and probabilities of initial hospitalization, acute rejection (AR), immunosuppressive therapy, adverse events, graft maintenance/failure, and dialysis for each treatment strategy. We compared only the 2.5 mg FTY720 + full dose CsA to the MMF + full dose CsA arms. All resources were valued in 2002 US dollars and the yet unknown cost of FTY720 was not included. Results: Event rates in study 1 (3 month outcomes) were 9.8% vs. 17.1% (AR), 2.4% vs. 4.9% (graft loss), and 2.4% vs. 0% (death) in the FTY720 and MMF arms respectively. Corresponding rates in study 2 (12 month outcomes) were 14.5% vs. 23.1 (AR), 11.8% vs. 10.3% (graft loss), and 2.7% and 2.6% (death), respectively. The incidence of serious Abstracts CMV was 0% vs. 4.9%, and 1.3% vs. 5.1%; the incidence of bradycardia reported as a serious adverse event was 1.2% vs. 0%, and 1.8% vs. 0%, respectively. These values were used to establish plausible ranges for each outcome at 12 months. Incorporating these outcomes into the economic model yielded total costs of $61,566 for the MMF arm and an incremental savings between $7,633 and $11,093 at 12 months for the FTY720 arm. This is attributable primarily to a reduced cost of treatment of AR, dialysis following graft loss, and maintenance immunosuppression. This savings excludes the cost of FTY720.

These results indicate that FTY720 may provide, beyond clinical benefits, an additional valuable potential economic benefit in de novo renal transplantation resulting from improved clinical immunosuppression. Intro: Preemptive renal transplantation requires that patients (pts) complete the transplant (txp) evaluation process prior to dialysis initiation. We compared rates of completion of the initial txp evaluation between pts not on chronic dialysis (PREDIAL) and pts already on chronic dialysis (DIAL), and whether factors that impact rates of completion are distributed differently between these groups. Methods: From 9/02 to 9/03, 253 pts undergoing their initial renal txp evaluation were enrolled in a prospective cohort study. Pts completed a questionnaire gathering information on demographics, views of txp and dialysis, and existence of potential living donors (LD). For the 133 pts who had ≥6 months follow-up, Cox proportional hazards models were fit to determine factors associated with time to completion of the txp evaluation. Results: Of the 133 pts, 60 (45.1%) were PREDIAL, while 77 (54.9%) were DIAL (74.0% hemo, 12.3% peritoneal, 13.7% unknown). 60.9% were male, with 54.1% Whites and 38.4% Blacks. After 6 months, 57 pts (42.9%) had completed their txp workup, defined as (1) listing for a cadaveric renal txp (84.2%) or receipt of a txp (5.3%), whichever occurred first; or (2) determination of medical unsuitability for a renal txp (10.5%). 61 pts were awaiting further evaluations (cardiovascular 50.6%, hepatologic 11.8%, GI 15.3%, Pap smear 17.7%, mammogram 14.1%, percentages sum to >100%). Age, gender, existence of potential LDs, and being PREDIAL were not associated with time to completion of the txp evaluation (P>0.25), but race and other factors were associated (Table) . Conclusions: In this interim analysis, faster completion of the txp workup was associated with White race, expectation of a cadaveric txp, and the influence of persons other than pts' physicians, but was not associated with dialysis status. INTRODUCTION: Transperitoneal laparoscopic live donor nephrectomy is becoming a standard technique for donor kidney retrieval. However, many authors have reported that about 5% of recipients required hemodialysis after renal transplantation due to poor renal function. This poor renal function may be caused by renal artery spasm or venous congestion caused by the high pressure of pneumoperitoneum during the procedure. Also, the transperitoneal approach always carries a potential risk of bowel injury and of late onset bowel obstruction due to adhesion of the intestines. Therefore, we tried to establish the technique of retroperitoneoscopic live donor nephrectomy (RPLDN) under low CO gas pressure as an ideal method in laparoscopic live donor nephrectomy. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Between July 2001 and June 2003, 120 live donor kidney grafts were procured by retroperitoneoscopic live donor nephrectomy. The patient was placed in a lateral decubitus position. A retroperitoneal working space was developed with a balloon dilator. Three retroperitoneoscopic ports were inserted in all cases. All procedures were performed through the retroperitoneal approach without opening the peritoneal cavity. Low (average 7mmHg) CO 2 gas pressure was employed during the procedure. Kidneys were retrieved through a 5-cm flank incision (initial 38 cases) or a 5-cm Pfannenstiel incision (recent 70 cases). The hand-assisted technique was not used in any of the cases. RESULTS: One hundred and ten cases were of left and 10 cases of right nephrectomy. Thirty-eight patients had more than 2 renal arteries (2-4 renal arteries). Donor nephrectomy was carried out successfully in all patients. The operative time was 293±75 min. One case was changed to open donor nephrectomy because of severe adhesion around the renal vein due to previous surgery. No serious complications, such as massive bleeding or bowel injury were encountered. Ureteral complications occurred in one patient and was treated with retrograde ureteral stenting. No patients required hemodialysis after transplantation due to acute tubular necrosis. Creatinine levels returned to normal levels within one week in all patients. CONCLUSION: RPLDN seems to be an excellent method without functional impairment of the transplanted renal graft. Laparoscopic live donor nephrectomy has been shown to lower the morbidity. Life threatening complications have, however, occurred. These complications have been related to severe bleedings or visceral injuries during the operation. To reduce the risk of these complications hand-assisted techniques have been introduced as well as the retroperitoneal approach. We have combined these techniques and introduced a handassisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy (HARS) technique. This presentation describes our experience with the first 50 consecutive cases.

The demographics of the donors and operative parameters are summarized in The operation: The left kidney was harvested in all cases. The operation starts with an infraumbilical incision without entering the abdomen and a hand port is introduced into the wound. A retroperitoneal cavity is created with blunt manual dissection. Gas is insufflated and a 12 mm port is placed lateral to the hand port. A 10 mm port is placed on the sub costal margin and a 5 mm port is placed in the flank.

Donors: In 4 cases it was not possible to loosen the peritoneum from the abdominal wall due to earlier operations and the operation was thus preformed intraperitonealy. In 10 cases a hole was caused in the peritoneum but this did not affect the operation or have any influence on the work space. There were no conversions. One donor was reoperated due to suspicion of a trocar hernia but with a negative finding. One donor developed pulmonary embolism 3 moths post operatively. Recipients: One ureter was anastomosed to the recipient ureter due to lesion of the donor's ureter. There was one urinary leakage. All kidneys except one had immediate onset of function (intraoperative venous thrombosis). The over all graft survival was 96% with a mean follow up of 490 (11-969) days. One graft was lost due to rejection after 20 months and one patient died with functioning graft due to myocardial infarction 7 months after the transplantation.

We conclude that the newly developed hand-assisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy (HARS) technique that was developed to minimize the risk of life threatening complications can be preformed with low complication rates, fairly short operating times and excellent graft outcome. It is proposed that this technique could become a new standard for endoscopic live donor nephrectomy. Introduction: Older donors (age ≥ 55 years) are increasingly being utilized both as deceased and living kidney donors. While kidney function is known to decline with age, little is known about the capacity of the older kidney to undergo adaptive hyperfiltration after uninephrectomy. The purpose of this study was to examine the ability of the older kidney to undergo adaptive renal hyperfiltration following uninephrectomy. Methods: 12 patients aged ≥ 55 who underwent uninephrectomy for kidney transplant donation or hypernephroma between 1 and 5 years ago were recruited for this study (UNX). These subjects were compared to a "control" group of 30 healthy volunteers (CRL), matched for age. Inclusion criteria for all subjects were: (1) lack of comorbid disease, including diabetes, hypertension, severe cardiovascular disease;(2) absence of significant proteinuria; and (3) serum creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL prior to surgery. Subjects underwent determination of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF) using the technique of inulin and PAH clearance, respectively. Results: (expressed as mean ± SEM) Age, at the time of study, did not differ between the groups (67y ± 2 in UNX vs. 67y ± 2 in CRL; p=0.9). Mean arterial blood pressure was also similar in both groups during the study (96 ± 2 mmHg in UNX vs. 96 ± 1 mmHg in CRL; p=0.9). GFR following uninephrectomy was compared to one kidney GFR (50% of the 2-kidney GFR) in controls. One-kidney GFR in the UNX group was significantly higher than the corresponding GFR in the CRL group (60 ± 4 mL/min vs. 41 ± 2 mL/min; p<0.0002) (figure 1). Similarly, RPF was higher in UNX than in CRL (289 ± 23 mL/min vs. 200 ± 12 mL/min; p<0.001). Conclusion: Subjects ≥ 55 years of age maintain the ability to undergo adaptive renal hyperfiltration and hyperperfusion following uninephrectomy. These adaptive responses are comparable in magnitude to values reported in younger subjects.Purpose: To compare outcomes for live kidney donors related to the surgical procedure, laparoscopic or open, during a two-year period. Method: An analysis was done of 11,415 living kidney donors who donated during 2000 and 2001 bason on OPTN data as of June 9, 2003. Comparison was made of laparoscopic versus open procedure type, comparing elements related to initial hospitalization, 6-month, and 1-year follow-up periods. Initial hospitalization elements included length of stay, blood transfusions, use of antihypertensives, incidence of pulmonary embolism or infection, and any return to the operating room. At 6-month and 1-year follow-ups, elements included blood pressure, creatinine, incidence of dialysis, any institution of maintenance dialysis or listing for kidney transplant, and any readmissions. Each data element was assessed; Donors with incomplete or questionable data were deleted from that analysis. Of 6264 laparoscopic donors, a maximum of 6256 had usable data; Of 5151 open donors, a maximum of 5072 had usable data. Results: During initial hospitalization, significant differences were seen between the two groups in length of stay, return to the OR, and infections. During the 6-month follow-up period, a significant difference was seen in incidence of dialysis. At one year, a significant difference was seen in use of antihypertensive drugs. No patient in either group required maintenance dialysis or listing for a kidney transplant. Although there were two donation-related deaths in the laparoscopic donor group, this was not found to be significant. The short and long-term risks of kidney donation appear to be low, however, the risk for obese donors has not been determined. Prevalence of obesity in the renal donor pool has forced consideration of potential long-term risks, including the development of diabetes mellitus or hypertension and secondary renal disease. We examined the perioperative course and early follow-up (mean 6±0.3 months, range 0-18) of 553 consecutive living renal donors (related 64%, unrelated 36%) who completed renal donation from 1/1/00 to 4/1/03 using body mass index (BMI) as a marker of obesity. We assessed surgical (operative time, peri-operative complications, length of hospital stay (LOS)), and medical outcomes (GFR by iothalamate clearance, blood pressure (BP) and fasting glucose (FG)).

Operative times were longer with BMI≥30 kg/m² (p<0.05). There were no differences in peri-operative complications or LOS (mean 2.2±0.1 days). Baseline BP (Dynamap) and FG were higher and rose incrementally with BMI. Lipid profiles were less favorable (higher total and LDL cholesterol and triglycerides, lower HDL) with higher BMI. There were no differences in age (mean 41.6±0.5 years) or serum creatinine (mean 1.1±0.01 mg/dL). Post nephrectomy BP and FG were higher with BMI group but did not differ from pre-donation values. Absolute GFR was greater with higher BMI before and after donor nephrectomy but did not differ once corrected for body surface area. There were no differences in degree of microalbuminuria (mean 8±1 mg pre, 9±1 post) across BMI groups. Our results support the short-term safety of living kidney donation for carefully selected obese renal donors. While these results are reassuring, continued monitoring of BP levels, glycemic control and renal function over time will be vital to our efforts to quantify health risks in obese donors. The calcineurin inhibitors (CNI), which have revolutionized the field of liver transplantation, are associated with significant nephrotoxicity potentially leading to renal failure. Switching patients with early CNI induced renal dysfunction to Sirolimus (SRL), a m-TOR inhibitor with no nephrotoxicity, has shown potential in reversing this problem. We present the interim results of a randomized trial to measure the effect of CNI withdrawal on early progressive renal dysfunction after liver transplantation. Methods: Stable liver recipients 6 months post transplant, with evidence of early renal dysfunction [24-hr creatinine clearance (CrCl) 50 -80ml/min] were included. Patients were randomized to receive either SRL based immunosuppression (n=20, SRL arm) or to continue CNI based immunosuppression (n=20, control arm). SRL was prescribed (3-5mg/day) to achieve a target serum level of 6-10 ng/ml and CNI was discontinued within 2 weeks. Renal function was assessed by 24-hour CrCl at 1 and 3, 9, and 12 months after enrollment. Results: 38 (95%) patients have completed nine months of follow-up and 66% have completed the trial. The initial mean baseline CrCl was similar (64mL/min SRL; 50mL/min control). Significant improvement in renal function was seen in the SRL arm, while renal function remained unchanged in the control arm. Two acute rejections occurred, one in each arm. They were successfully treated with a steroid recycle. One patient on SRL required resumption of cyclosporine for pruritis. Three SRL recipients and two control patients showed altered lipid profiles necessitating lipid lowering agents. Four patients (30%) on SRL reported mouth sores that resolved spontaneously within one month.Conclusions: Interim data from this prospective, randomized trial reveals SRL based immunosuppression appears to be a safe and effective alternative to CNI in liver transplant recipients. Withdrawal of CNI provides significant functional recovery of renal function in stable liver transplant recipients with early renal dysfunction. Liver transplantation is an accepted therapy in older patients. Older and younger recipients are usually given a similar intensity of immunosuppression. We propose that older patients may be relatively over-immunosuppressed and experience associated excess mortality. SRTR data for 26,946 adult liver transplant (txp) recipients during 1993-2001 were used to determine post-txp survival and the incidence of rejection in the first year posttxp by age group. Patients missing immunosuppression therapy data or who died within 30 days post-txp were excluded. Logistic regression models were fit to determine the odds of treated rejection, adjusted for recipient race, ethnicity, sex, diagnosis, living or deceased donor, induction antibody treatment, and year of txp. Cox regression models from day 30 until 1 and 5 years post-txp were fit to examine all cause mortality risk by age group and that due specifically to infection and/or malignancy (Inf-Mal), adjusted for the factors above as well as recipient creatinine, life support, status 1, cold ischemia time, and ABO compatibility. The incidence of treatment for rejection in the first year ranged from 44% for age 18-39 to 32% for age 60+. The adjusted odds of rejection in the first year were significantly lower for older than younger patients (see Table) . Both overall and Inf-Mal specific 1year adjusted mortality risks were significantly higher for older than younger patients (see Table) . Mortality risk for the oldest patients was more than twice that for the youngest (overall mortality HR=2.28, p<0.0001; Inf-Mal-specific HR=2.07, p<0.0001). Results at 5 years showed 76% higher overall mortality risk and 62% higher Inf-Mal-specific risk for 60+ than 18-39 year olds (p<0.0001 for both). Current immunosuppression regimens may expose older patients to excess mortality risk due to infection and malignancy, as a consequence of relative overimmunosuppression. We hypothesize that survival of older liver transplant recipients might be improved by reducing the intensity of immunosuppression. Background: Effects of Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) on hepatitis C virus (HCV) recurrence following orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) remain controversial. Further, MMF pharmocpkinetics after OLT are yet to be investigated. Methods: MMF effects on HCV recurrence following OLT for HCV was evaluated in a prospective randomized open-label study in OLT recipients. Protocol biopsies were performed at 3, 6, 12 and 24 months. At days 7 and 90 post-OLT, mycophenolic acid (MPA) concentrations were measured by a validated HPLC method with ultraviolet detection from serial blood draws over a 12 hr period following MMF dosing. Dose normalized area under the curve (AUC) were calculated by noncompartmental methods. Results: Twenty patients were enrolled in each arm. In the first, recipients received Tacrolimus (Tac) and Prednisone that was tapered over a 3 months period, In the second arm patients received Tac, and Prednisone that was tapered over one month, and MMF that was orally given as 500 or 1000 mg (creatinine >2 or <2 mg/dl) twice daily for one year. Average age was 53±9.2 yrs and average follow-up was 185±195 days. Model for End Stage Liver Disease (MELD) scores, were 24.9 ± 6 and 23.9 ± 7.5, in each arm, respectively (P NS). Three deaths occurred in each arm that were caused by sepsis and multiorgan failure in 5 patients and severe pulmonary hypertension in one. One patient in each arm underwent re-OLT for recurrent disease. No significant difference was observed in HCV RNA, ALT, AST levels measured at 1, 3, 6 and 12 months post-OLT. However, evidence of histological HCV recurrence was detected at 3 months in both groups. Hepatitis activity index (HAI) for the two arms was 2.8±0.5 vs 3.1±0.4 (P NS) at 3 months, and 6.8±1.5 vs 7.5±1.4 at 6 months, respectively. Similarly, there was no difference in fibrosis scores 0.2±0.5 vs 0.15±0.5 (P NS) at 3 months, and 0.6±0.3.5 vs 1.5±1.4 at 6 months, respectively. Day 7 and day 90 AUC were 20.42±9.96 and 21.16±8.14 mg h/L. One patient with low AUC (8.8 mg h/L) experienced a rejection episode at day 40. AUC did not appear to significantly differ among patients based on level and timing of recurrence and did not correlate with trough drug levels.

Background: Post-liver transplant immunosuppression management is difficult in recipients with hepatitis C (HCV). Over-aggressive immunosuppression may lead to severe HCV recurrence and sub-optimal immunosuppression may lead to graft rejection. Biopsies to assess HCV recurrence versus rejection are often difficult to interpret due to similar histopathologic processes. A new assay (ImmuKnow™, Cylex Inc., Columbia, MD), assesses quantitatively the cell-mediated immune response by measuring the ATP release in CD4 + T cells when stimulated by phytohemagglutinin. Using this assay, the cell-mediated immune response in HCV post-liver transplant recipients was correlated with biopsy findings. We hypothesized that this assay would differentiate HCV recurrence compared to acute cellular rejection in HCV liver transplant recipients. Methods: Blood from 24 liver transplant recipients with HCV undergoing protocol or diagnostic liver biopsy were obtained and assayed for cell-mediated immune response using the ImmuKnow™ assay. ATP release was classified as: low (<225ng/ml); moderate (226-524ng/ml); and strong (>525ng/ml). Biopsies were reviewed by pathologists blinded to assay results. Results: In recipients with evidence of rejection on biopsy (n=6), 3/6 (50%) had a strong ATP release, 2/6 (33.3%) had a moderate release, and 1/6 (16.7%) had a low release. In recipients with recurrent HCV on biopsy (n=16), 0/16 had a strong ATP release, 4/16 (25%) had a moderate release, and 12/16 (75%) had a low release. Two recipients with HCV with evidence of neither rejection nor HCV recurrence on biopsy had low and moderate releases, respectively. Conclusions: This initial evaluation suggests that rejection is predominately evident in HCV liver transplant recipients with strong/ moderate ATP release. This finding implies sub-optimal immunosuppression and relatively intact host immunity. HCV recurrence is predominately observed in recipients with low/moderate ATP release suggesting adequate and/or possible over-immunosuppression. In this latter group of recipients, reduction of immunosuppression may be necessary, in addition to, HCV anti-viral therapy. This assay when combined with histopathological findings may be helpful in post-transplant monitoring of immunosuppression in HCV liver transplant recipients. Background: In the viral DNA polymerase gene of human cytomegalovirus (CMV), mutations on 24 codons were experimentally proven to confer drug resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscarnet (Chou et al., 1993 , JID 2003 . Purpose: To evaluate the virus infecting liver transplant recipients that were slow to respond to antiviral therapy. Methods and Materials: High risk liver transplant recipients were routinely followed (weekly to biweekly) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for the human CMV virus and at time of seroconversion, preemptive therapy is begun with ganciclovir 5mg/Kg Q12H. Patients were classified as responders, slow responders and clinically resistant patients. Serum samples of all patients (n = 12) converting between January and Nov. 2003 (n = 24) were collected and stored at -80° c. Long PCR was used to amplify CMV DNA of 2647 bp corresponding to nucleotides 897-2934 in the DNA polymerase gene of the serum samples collected. Amplicons were sequenced in ABI 3100 genetic analyzer. The sequence information was analyzed with DNASTAR software, i.e. in multiple sequence alignments; nucleotide positions against these mutations on the 24 codons were scrutinized to determine drug resistant CMV. Correlation with this lab results is then compared to clinical findings. Results: Of the 12 seroconverting, 4 were pediatric (mean age: 7.1 years) patients with one seroconverting to Epstein Barr (EBV). Mean time to CMV conversion was 48.2 ± 6.5 days. Of the 12 patients, 6 responded within one week to ganciclovir with a drop in CMV by PCR levels. Of the remaining 6 patients, 3 patients were slow to respond to ganciclovir taking 10.6 ± 4.2 days to respond to ganciclovir and the remaining 3 patients were switched to foscarnet. The nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) proteins are a family of transcription factors whose activation is controlled by calcineurin, a calcium-dependent phosphatase. Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus, commonly used in clinical transplantation, are known to inhibit the activation of NFAT family of transcription factors. Nevertheless, the role of individual NFAT family members has not been explored in transplantation. In a previous study, our group demonstrated that naive T precursor cells that are doubly deficient in NFATc2 and NFATc3 intrinsically differentiate into Th2-secreting cells. In this study we sought to explore the role of these molecules in both skin and cardiac transplantation models in vivo. To this end, NFATc2/c3 doubledeficient BALB/c mice (DKO) received full thickness trunk skin or vascularized cardiac allografts from fully MHC-mismatched BALB.B donors. The allograft survival was significantly prolonged in DKO recipients of skin grafts (18.9±2.9, n=8 versus 12.1±1, n=9 in controls p<0.0001) and somewhat less in recipients of heart allografts (15.4±0.6, n=6 versus 8±0.3, n=5, p=0.0002 ). The delay in allograft rejection was not due to inability of DKO T cells to respond to alloantigens, as mixed lymphocyte reaction of purified DKO CD4+ T cells to irradiated BALB.B splenocytes was comparable to that of wild-type control CD4+ T cells. To elaborate the role of IL-4 in prolonging allograft survival, DKO mice were next crossed with BALB/c IL-4 deficient mice to generate mice triply-deficient for NFATc2, NFATc3 and IL-4. TKO mice rejected both skin (13.5±0, n=4, p=NS) and cardiac allografts (7.5±0.4, n=8, p=NS) as promptly as wild-type BALB/ c controls. This is the first report demonstrating that NFATc2 and NFATc3 play an important role in transplant rejection, at least in part through their ability to control IL-4 production. Better understanding of the contribution of NFAT molecules to the regulation of the immune response will help develop better strategies for tolerance induction in future. 1 1 Transplant Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA; 2 Department of Blood Transfusion, University of Miami, Miami, FL; 3 Pathology, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA; 4 Transplant Biology Reseach Center, Massachusetts General Hospital, Charlestown, MA. Background: Blockade of the CD40/CD154 pathway has provided one of the most robust strategies to regulate auto or alloimmune responses. The successful clinical application of this strategy for organ transplantation or autoimmune disease therapy, however, was delayed when initial clinical trials suggested an unusually high incidence of thromboembolic complications in patients receiving anti-CD154 monoclonal antibody (mAb)treatment. Thrombophilia was also associated with anti-CD154 mAb treatment in nonhuman primate renal allograft recipients.These studies were undertaken to clarify the mechanisms involved and to define an effective prophylactic regimen for this complication.Methods: All monkeys were treated with a nonmyeloablative conditioning regimen which consists of low dose TBI (1.5 Gy x2), thymic irradiation(7 Gy), ATG, combined donor bone marrow and kidney transplants with or without splenectomy (day 0), followed by a one-month course of cyclosporine. A short course (20mg/kg/day x 2 or 6) of anti-CD154 mAB (5c8) was added in eighty recipients.Result: Without 5c8, no recipients developed thromboembolic complications (0/67). Among 11 recipients who received 5c8 without anticoagulation, 2/6 without splenectomy and 3/5 with splenectomy developed thromboembolism. Initial in vitro studies suggested that CD40 expressed on platelets may interact with the mAb possibly leading to a lowered threshhold of activation by platelet agonists such as epinephrine.With addition of perioperative heparin, the thromboembolic incidence was decreased to 2/ 10. No further improvement was observed by adding intraoperative prostaglandin E1 (PGE1). However, addition of Ketorolac, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, to PGE1 and heparin decreased the incidence of thrombosis (1/8) . Most recently, we have found that Ketorolac administration alone resulted in no thrombosis in 25 consecutive recipients. Conclusion: Ketorolac is remarkably effective in preventing thromboembolism associated with anti-CD154 mAb treatment, further suggesting the mechanism underlying this complication is related to platelet activation leading to enhanced aggregation. Dendritic cells (DC) are professional antigen-presenting cells with the unique ability to initiate and regulate immune responses. In the transplantation setting, both donorderived and recipient DC contribute to allorejection by initiating T cell activation and proliferation. DC, particularly in an immature state, are also inherently tolerogenic and can prolong allograft survival. Sustained immaturity in vivo, however, remains to be achieved. Among many approaches to generation of stably immature DC, pharmacologic modification stands out as a promising and clinically applicable option. Rapamycin (Rapa) is a potent immunosuppressant with well-recognized T cell inhibitory effects.

Here, we examined the impact of in vitro-generated, Rapa-treated, alloAg-pulsed recipient myeloid DC (Rapa-DC) on murine vascularized heart graft survival and the underlying immunological mechanisms. DC were generated from C3H/HeJ (H-2K k ) mouse bone marrow in the presence of clinically relevant concentration of Rapa (10 ng/ml). Following pulsing with alloAg [freeze-thawed donor (C57BL/10; H-2K b ) splenocytes], the DC were infused i.v. (1.5x10 6 cells) to recipient C3H mice. Rapa-DC were able to localize to T cell areas of the spleen, similar to control DC. Unlike the latter, however, they prolonged graft survival significantly when infused 7 days prior to transplantation (MST 23.9 vs. 10.4 days, p<0.005). This effect was Ag-specific (MST 12 days for Rapatreated, 3 rd party Ag-pulsed DC) and could be enhanced by administration of minimallyeffective dose (1 mg/kg/day, i.m.; 10 days) of FK-506 (MST 47.8 days). Studies to elucidate the underlying mechanisms showed that Rapa significantly inhibited spontaneous and LPS-induced maturation of DC, while it did not block alloAg uptake. Rapa-DC were poor stimulators of syngeneic T cells, presumably due to their impaired ability to present alloAg via the indirect pathway. T cells primed by Rapa-DC showed decreased capacity to produce IL-2 and IFN-γ, and were hyporesponsive to rechallenge in an Ag-specific manner. This hyporesponsiveness was reversible by exogenous IL-2. Together, these results show that a single infusion of pharmacologically-modified, alloAg-pulsed DC can induce Ag-specific T cell hyporesponsiveness via the indirect pathway and prolong graft survival significantly. This strategy constitutes a novel approach to cell-based therapy of graft rejection applicable in the clinic.It is now well established that the co-stimulatory molecules CD28 and CD40L are necessary for complete T cell activation and play a crucial role in mediating alloimmune responses. However, the role of other co-stimulatory molecules in these responses has yet to be fully elucidated. The TNFR member CD30 is a co-stimulatory molecule that is induced on alloactivated T cells, marks the major proliferating T cell population in response to allogeneic APC and CD30+ T cells are the primary source of IFN-γ and IL-5. Although this evidence suggests that CD30 co-stimulation might modulate alloimmune responses, the function of the CD30 molecule on alloactivated T cells remains unclear. Therefore, the current study was designed to test the hypothesis that CD30 acts as a co-stimulatory molecule in allogeneic responses and directly modulates T cell proliferation and cytokine production. Negatively selected T cells from C57Bl/ 6 wild type (H-2 b ) or CD30 -/mice (H-2 b ) were co-cultured in vitro with mitomycin C treated Balb/C (H-2 d ) splenocytes as allogeneic stimulators. Cells were harvested after 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 days of culture and the extent of proliferation and cytokine production was assessed via [³H]thymidine incorporation and ELISA, respectively. In parallel, the frequency of cytokine producing T cells was assessed by ELISPOT. Separate groups of animals were used to examine the frequency of cytokine producing T cells in response to allostimulation in vivo. Cell proliferation was reduced by 51% in CD30 -/compared with wild type T cells at the peak of proliferation (day 3) following allogeneic stimulation. IFN-γ production was abrogated in CD30 -/-T cells compared with wild type T cells on day 5 (399 pg/ml vs. 1583 pg/ml; 74%) following in vitro stimulation, while no differences were observed in IL-2 production. Moreover, CD30 -/-T cells displayed a lower frequency of IFN-γ production (406 spots/106 cells vs. 764 spots/ 106 cells; 46%) then wild type controls. A similar trend of reduced frequency of IFNγ producing cells in CD30 -/mice was observed after in vivo allostimulation. No differences were observed in the frequency of cytokine produced per T cell, for IL-2, IL-4, or IL-5 following in vitro or in vivo allostimulation. Taken together these results indicate that CD30 contributes to alloimmune responses by modulating T cell activation and IFN-γ responses to alloantigen. Graft function at six months post-transplant is a powerful predictor of long-term graft and patient survival. Using a multivariant linear regression modeling, the impact of acute rejection, delayed graft function, maintenance immunosuppression, en bloc vs. solitary transplantation and HLA mismatch on the abbreviated MDRD GFR was determined in 40,155 patients who underwent cadaveric renal transplant between 1991 and 2000. Only patients with graft survival at least six months, and who had complete data regarding donor and recipient age, gender and race, acute rejection in the first six months, delayed graft function, HLA mismatch, solitary vs en bloc transplant and creatinine at six months were included. Acute rejection in the first six months, delayed graft function and rapamycin treatment were with associated with a 6.13, 4.03 and 1.72 ml/min/1.73m 2 reduction in GFR, respectively. En bloc transplantation, treatment with FK506, MMF and azathioprine were associated with 7.94, 3.07, 2.73 and 0.95 ml/min/1.73m² improvement in GFR, respectively. Over the decade, 3.94 ml/min/1.73m 2 improvement in GFR was unaccounted for by factors in the model. Cyclosporine treatment, steroid treatment and HLA mismatch did not significantly effect GFR. In conclusion, acute rejection and delayed graft function are associated with significant reductions in GFR at six months. Even after adjusting for clinical acute rejection in the model, FK 506, MMF and azathioprine were associated with significant improvements in GFR suggesting that other immunologic and nonimmunologic factors like reduced subclinical rejection and nephrotoxicity may be important benefits of these medications. Further study is required to determine if this translates into better long-term graft and patient survival. The effect of pre-transplant renal replacement therapy (RRT) modality on allograft and recipient survival outcome is not clear. We studied allograft and recipient survival using USRDS records from patients receiving kidney or kidney-pancreas transplant (Tx) from 1/1/90 through 12/31/99, with the follow-up period through 12/31/00 (n=92,844, 60% males, 70% white, 23% black). Pretransplant and predominant RRT modality during end-stage renal disease period, as well as specific combinations of the RRT modalities were evaluated. Cox models were adjusted for donor and recipient characteristics (demographic data, comorbidities) and Tx procedure characteristics. For graft survival (reference modality -hemodialysis (HD)) the Cox model demonstrated the disadvantage of a Tx immediately prior to the Tx of interest (HR 1.65, p<0.001), while peritoneal dialysis (PD) as a modality immediately prior to Tx predicts better graft outcome (HR 0.97 p<0.05) (Figure) . When the predominant modality was analyzed, both PD (HR 0.97 p<0.05) and Tx (HR 0.86 p<0.001) had a protective effect for the graft survival compared to HD. Any combination or any single modality (except for Tx only, PD+HD and None) had protective effects on graft survival compared to HD alone. PD+HD, and "None" were associated with non-significantly higher risk than HD. When recipient survival was evaluated, both prior Tx (0.798 p<0.005) and PD (0.94 p<0.005) had a protective effect compared to HD. Better recipient survival was also associated with both PD (HR 0.96 p<0.05) and Tx (HR 0.82 p<0.001) as predominant pre-Tx RRT modalities. Results suggest the beneficial role of PD for allograft and recipient survival. In our center we have observed a powerful combined impact on graft failure of CMVdisease and HLA-DR mismatching in renal transplant recipients who survived beyond the end of prophylaxis at six-months post-transplant. Five-year graft survival was 16% in patients with CMV-disease and 2 HLA-DR mismatches and 78% otherwise. No pattern of benefit from HLA-DR matching was observed unless a patient had CMVdisease. We sought to determine if this is occurring nationwide. METHODS: Patient records for all adult renal transplant recipients surviving sixmonths post-transplant were drawn from the Scientific Renal Transplant Registry database between 1997 and 2002. CMV-disease was not recorded in the database so the association of graft survival with HLA-DR mismatches was compared in patients believed to be at high risk of CMV-disease (CMV D+/R-) with patients believed to be at low risk (D-/R-). Donor CMV-serology was not available for the large majority of living donors; thus recipients of living donor kidneys were excluded. RESULTS: Outcomes of 8,157 D+/R-and 5,932 D-/R-cadaveric renal transplant recipients were examined. No association with death with a functioning graft was observed between the interaction of CMV-serology and HLA-DR mismatches. However, death censored, so called "immunologic", graft failure was significantly associated with the interaction of CMV and HLA-DR mismatches. The relative hazard of immunologic graft failure for D+/R-compared to D-/R-patients was increased by 55% (P = 0.007) with 2 HLA-DR mismatches, 30% (P = 0.038) with 1 HLA-DR mismatch, and 3% (P = 0.77) with 0 HLA-DR mismatches. Multivariate analysis confirmed the size and significance of this interaction. Assuming a 20% CMV-disease incidence in D+/R-and 5% in D-/R-patients, compard to patients without CMV-disease our observed results would be consistent with a 550% increased hazard of graft failure with CMVdisease and 2 HLA-DR mismatches and a 350% increased hazard of graft failure with CMV-disease and 1 HLA-DR mismatch. CONCLUSION: National data is consistent with our center's observation of an interaction between CMV-disease and HLA-DR mismatches that is associated with graft failure. While the mechanisms of this interaction require further study, we find it of extreme importance that CMV-disease be avoided in patients with HLA-DR mismatches. Treatment regimens to extend graft survival are needed for the unfortunate HLA-DR mismatched patients experiencing CMV-disease.
